Art connoisseurs can also admire works by Russian greats like Chagall and Kandinsky.

A bronze work by Finnis sculptor Wäinö Valdemar Aaltonen. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Founded in 1912, the museum is located in the historic centre of Moscow, not far from the Kremlin. As far as I can recall, it was also relatively close to Novotel Moscow City, where I was staying. I took the metro from Vystavochnaya station, almost next door to my hotel, visited the Kremlin, and then headed towards Kropotkinskaya station, from where it was just a few minutes’ walk to the Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts.

The museum possesses one of the world’s largest art collections, spanning from Ancient Egypt and Greece to modern times. Today, its holdings comprise around 7,00,000 works of art from different epochs. The jewel of the collection is French art of the 19th and 20th centuries—one of the most celebrated collections of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings in the world.

The main building houses artworks from various countries, covering periods from antiquity to the early 19th century. This includes an extensive collection of plaster casts of sculptures from antiquity, the Middle Ages, and the Renaissance, as well as original paintings, sculptures, graphics, and decorative arts.

Venus after Bath, a bronze made sculpture by Bologna Giovanni, an Italian Rennaisaunce sculptor. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Of particular interest are the ancient Egyptian collections, including Priam’s Treasure—a collection of 259 items comprising jewellery, vessels, hammer-axes, and artefacts fashioned from rock crystal, also referred to as “Trojan Gold.” The treasure was discovered by Heinrich Schliemann during excavations at the site of Troy between 1872 and 1890.

The Pushkin Museum also displays significant works by leading European artists such as Rubens, Rembrandt, Botticelli, El Greco, Poussin, and Watteau. Some 26 of the museum’s galleries are dedicated to a wide-ranging collection of works by master painters of the 19th and 20th centuries.

It is impossible for anyone to thoroughly inspect all the fascinating paintings, sculptures, and artefacts that make up the Pushkin Museum’s rich treasure trove, though I tried to visit as many galleries as possible in a single afternoon.

I was particularly fascinated by the gems from master painter Pablo Picasso, including some of his most notable works: Old Blind Man with Boy, The Two Acrobats, Portrait of Ambroise Vollard, and Woman with a Fan. One simply cannot resist spending time in silent reflection before the masterstrokes of legendary French visual artist Henri Matisse, renowned for his use of colour and original draughtsmanship.

Harlequin and his Companion (Les deux saltimbanques - The Two Acrobats) by Pablo Picasso. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Spanish painter and printmaker Francisco Goya’s mysterious etching Disparate de Carnaval (Carnival) is also on display at Pushkin. Created around 1816 as part of Goya’s Disparates series but published posthumously in 1864, Carnival depicts masked figures in chaotic, dreamlike revelry, reflecting societal absurdity and human irrationality through Goya’s signature blend of social commentary and dark fantasy.

Visitors can also admire masterpieces such as Bacchanalia by Peter Paul Rubens, the most influential artist of the Flemish Baroque tradition. The bacchanalian theme refers to ancient Greco-Roman festivals honouring Bacchus (Dionysus), the god of wine, characterised by wild, ecstatic, and often drunken revelry, fertility rites, music, and dancing. Rubens painted several works depicting bacchanalian themes, but Bacchanalia (also known as Dionysian Rhapsody), dated around 1615 and housed in the Pushkin Museum in Moscow, remains the most famous among them.

Writer at one of the Pushkin Museum galleries. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

title: RobinRafan Wins AI Educator of the Year Award in Content Creation at London
body:
ATV Iconic Star Fashion and Business Awards Season 9 lit up London on November 2, 2025, held at the MayFair Venue, High Road, Romford, United Kingdom.

The event brought together stars from both Banglas, including celebrated actors, actresses, directors, fashion designers, and models.

Indian National Film Award winner Rituporna Sengupta graced the ceremony with her presence, adding major glamour to the night. A dynamic fashion show also set the runway ablaze, featuring South Asian designers and emerging creative talents.

ATV USA’s President & CEO Akash Rahman and chairperson Esha Rahman attended the gala and presented honours across multiple categories.

This year’s awardees included several notable names: Rituporna Sengupta (India), Apu Biswas (Bangladesh), Actor Nirob Hossain (Bangladesh), Puja Cherry (Bangladesh), Singer Rizia Parveen (Bangladesh), and many other distinguished personalities from the entertainment and fashion industries. The ceremony showcased a strong cultural bridge between India, Bangladesh, and the global Bangla-speaking diaspora.

Content creator RobinRafan received the AI Educator of the Year award in Content Creation for his groundbreaking work in AI-driven content development, educational contributions, and authorship.

The jury board selected him for his remarkable impact on transforming modern content creation through AI, and for consistently guiding creators towards more efficient, innovative, and creative workflows.

Over the past year, he has been relentlessly training content creators, helping them master AI tools and inspiring them to produce creative content one after another.

Founder & CEO of Iconic Star & Fashion Awards added: “Throughout the entire year, RobinRafan worked tirelessly to uplift content creators. Through training and hands-on guidance, he helped them become more skilled and more creative with AI. He truly deserves this award.”

As RobinRafan is currently in the US, the award was received on his behalf by a close friend present at the event. This achievement becomes another major international milestone for him after receiving honours in US.

Reacting to the recognition, RobinRafan said he remains committed to using AI in content creation in a creative and meaningful way, while helping other creators evolve. “Awards like this increase my responsibility even more,” he stated, emphasizing his mission to inspire the next generation of digital creators.

The 9th edition of the ATV Iconic Star Awards once again blended fashion, entertainment, and innovation, making it one of the standout cultural events of the year.

title: Simply Bhutan
body:
In one go, it is impossible to explore the length and breadth of a country—regardless of how large or small its geographical area may be. This is true even for a country like Bhutan, where nature is stunning, heritage is rich, and the public perception of prosperity is not confined to economic growth alone. Here, prosperity is less about gross domestic product (GDP) and more about gross national happiness (GNH).

While GDP measures a nation’s economic output, GNH is a holistic alternative pioneered by Bhutan. It assesses overall well-being by incorporating psychological, environmental, cultural, and governance factors beyond mere financial indicators, aiming for sustainable and equitable development rather than pure economic growth. Essentially, GDP asks: “How much wealth are we making?” while GNH asks: “Are we living well, sustainably?”

Artefacts at Simply Bhutan. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Ideally located in the heart of the national capital, Thimphu, Simply Bhutan is a highly interactive living museum that offers an immersive introduction to traditional Bhutanese life. A visit to Simply Bhutan can serve as a rewarding prelude for tourists, offering a glimpse of what to expect from this landlocked Himalayan kingdom—the “Land of the Thunder Dragon”—its deep-rooted Buddhist culture, dramatic landscapes of monasteries and fortresses, and its commitment to GNH by balancing tradition with modernity.

During my business trip to Thimphu earlier this year, when the cool February breeze was pleasant and the Bhutanese sky wore an unusually vivid blue, I stepped into Simply Bhutan one afternoon and was greeted with a shot of ara (rice wine). A guided experience allowed me to explore various cultural aspects firsthand—from dressing in traditional Bhutanese attire and learning how ara is distilled, to being introduced to dragon masks of different denominations, traditional kitchen utensils, culinary practices, and even dancing to the tunes of Bhutanese folk songs sung by local artists.

Dance to the tune of a greeting song at Simply Bhutan. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

As a novice, I also tried my hand at archery and khuru (a local dart game), observed the construction techniques of traditional Bhutanese houses, and learned how Bhutanese preserve dried chili peppers—a major component of their cuisine. Near the museum entrance, artists performed a welcoming song accompanied by a dance choreographed to depict the process of rice distillation used to make high-quality ara.

Further inside the museum, a wide array of artefacts is on display, allowing visitors to witness and admire the artisan skills of the Bhutanese people, particularly the intricate woodwork seen in traditional kitchen utensils.

Traditional Bhutanese kitchen utencils at Simply Bhutan. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Simply Bhutan is a cultural conservation project dedicated to preserving Bhutan’s heritage while creating employment opportunities for local youth. The museum’s architecture reflects traditional Bhutanese design, featuring repurposed timber, doors, window frames, and other materials salvaged from demolished houses. This sustainable approach ensures that Bhutan’s architectural heritage remains alive for future generations.

Later, I enjoyed performances of traditional songs and dances that have been passed down through generations and are now performed by young Bhutanese artists with remarkable skill and eloquence. They also encouraged visitors to participate in a few dance steps, which were simple yet graceful.

Artefacts at Simply Bhutan. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Once the dance and musical performances concluded, I was offered a traditional Bhutanese dinner. It was sumptuous and deeply satisfying, to say the least. While Bhutanese cuisine bears influences from neighbouring countries such as India, China, and Nepal, its defining hallmark is spiciness, with chilies at the heart of nearly every dish.

A Bhutanese meal. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

Datsi—a locally available cheese with a texture and taste similar to feta, but without the salt—is used abundantly in many dishes. The Bhutanese diet is rich in meat, poultry, grains, and vegetables. Both dried and fresh chilies are used generously, either to spice up stew-like curries or as the main ingredient, usually accompanied by steamed rice, the primary source of carbohydrates. My personal favourite is red rice, valued for its nutritious qualities, delicate texture, and nutty, earthy flavour—especially when served with tender chicken pieces stir-fried with bell peppers.

Dried chillies at Simply Bhutan. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

When I first noticed rows of dried chili peppers hanging along the sidewalls inside the Simply Bhutan museum, I could already imagine how central chilies must be to Bhutanese cuisine. Later, I discovered that chilies are almost a staple in many Bhutanese delicacies. Central to Bhutanese cuisine, the humble chili—known locally as ema—is not merely a spice but a defining feature of the nation’s gastronomic identity.

Visitors in traditional Bhutanese dress at Simply Bhutan. Photo: Dhaka Tribune

title: Winter mornings made warm: Choosing the right room heater
body:
Winter mornings can be bone-chilling, with icy floors, cold bathrooms, and a persistent chill that no blanket, hoodie, or thick socks seem to fight off. In such conditions, a reliable room heater is not just a luxury but an essential household appliance.

Choosing the right heater involves more than picking the first model you see. Factors such as electricity consumption, safety, air quality, health risks, and ease of use are crucial to ensure comfort without compromising safety or efficiency.

The purchase price is only part of the total expense. Electricity consumption can significantly increase overall costs, especially if the heater runs daily for long hours throughout winter. For example, a 1,500-watt heater running five hours a day for 90 days at Tk8 per unit would cost around Tk5,400 for the season.

Energy-efficient models, though often more expensive upfront, can reduce electricity bills substantially over time. Features such as a thermostat, timer, and eco mode help control usage and avoid unnecessary expenses. Considering both initial cost and long-term electricity use ensures your heater is economical and effective.

A winter room heater is a vital investment for comfort and well-being during the cold season. Choosing the right one requires balancing room size, wattage, safety, energy efficiency, health considerations, noise, portability, and long-term cost.

No single heater suits every room, so thoughtful selection is key. With the right choice, winter mornings can be warm, comfortable, and worry-free, allowing you to enjoy the season without shivering or compromising safety.

title: Apple’s new MIE security feature worth your peace of mind?
body:
Apple released their new iPhone 17 series a few months ago, but aside from the new features and improvements, the most exciting security feature of these new phones was not even mentioned in its keynote or really advertised at all.

And I think it significantly raises the bar in terms of security for everyone.

With Apple’s new A19 chip being based on the ARMv9A architecture, iOS now supports the memory tagging extension feature. And this comes from an announcement on the Apple security research blog in September.

Apple calls their implementation “Memory Integrity Enforcement (MIE) and published a technical breakdown on their security blog.

It combines some existing memory safety features in iOS with ARM's Memory Tagging Extension (MTE), which has been seen in some Android smartphones for a few years now.

Let’s explore how it aims to make cyberattacks on iOS devices significantly more difficult.

MTE is a hardware feature introduced by ARM as part of the ARMv8.5-A architecture in 2019. ARM built it as a debugging tool for software developers.

Apps need to store data in your phone's memory (RAM), and they reserve this space through a process called memory allocation.

Unfortunately, if these allocations are not strictly validated, apps can inadvertently or maliciously access memory outside of what they were assigned.

What MTE does is essentially tag every single memory allocation with a secret code.

The hardware then ensures that every future request to access that memory is only granted if the request contains that same secret.

If the request does not contain the secret code, for example, because it came from an app other than the one that was allocated in the first place, then the app that is making the request crashes and the event is logged by the operating system.

The goal behind this was to help developers identify these fatal errors immediately. Why is this a big deal for security?

According to reports from both Microsoft and Google, over 70% of security vulnerabilities identified in their products are attributable to issues related to memory safety.

And many of the high-profile vulnerabilities that we have seen over the years were caused by a lack of memory safety.

Security researchers identified that MTE could function as a continuous tool for monitoring and preventing security exploits, in addition to its use as a debugging tool.

The Google Pixel has actually been using MTE in some capacity since the Pixel 8.

Most exploits against iOS devices rely on memory corruption bugs. These are bugs where, because of faulty system logic, an attacker can write to out-of-bounds memory or type-confuse objects to corrupt important parts of the process data and ultimately take control of the system.

Memory corruption bugs have been around forever and are unlikely to go away completely. Even with the latest iOS versions, we see many bugs of this category being fixed in patch updates regularly.

It would be infeasible to aim for a bug-free iOS. So instead, Apple has focused on making these bugs as difficult as possible to exploit.

They have already done a great job at this in their software and hardware enhancements over the years, with features like pointer authentication codes to mitigate control flow hijacking, zone sequestering, and other proprietary hardware mitigations like Kernel Text Read and Write (KTRR) and Page Protection Layer (PPL).

Apple's MIE is supposed to be the final nail in the coffin, potentially ending memory corruption exploitation in iOS completely.

Apple uses MIE to secure the kernel and over 70 userland processes in its operating system.

They also make MIE available as an opt-in feature for app developers, meaning that it is very likely the apps you use, which need the highest levels of security, hopefully as instant messengers or web browsers, will probably enable it on their own soon.

This usage is a step above the typical MTE configuration on Android, which uses it less substantially across the operating system itself.

It works much like an address sanitizer, a common software debugging tool.

The problem with software-based address sanitizers is that they have a significant overhead due to the inefficiency of performing extra logic on every single memory access. It would not be a good idea to ship a production device with a software-based address sanitizer active because performance would take too much of a hit.

The cool thing about the MTE feature is that it leverages new hardware instructions available in the ARMV9A architecture that implement the functionality of a software address sanitizer, but in a hardware-backed way.

These new CPUs have built-in circuitry to handle the sanity checks. So, performance takes no real hit.

If you inspect the kernel itself on the iPhone 17 running the latest iOS version, you can see these new MTE instructions present in the kernel cache binary.

The first new instruction you will see is the IRG instruction, which inserts a random tag into a pointer.

Now, much like pointer authentication codes, the IRG instruction generates a random 4-bit tag and inserts it into the top, unused bits of a given pointer.

The STG instruction takes that tag and writes it into a special private shadow memory region that holds tags for every 16-byte chunk of memory.

Once a pointer and its corresponding memory are tagged, any subsequently executed memory access instruction will trigger an exception if the tags are ever found to be mismatched.

Checking for mismatched tags does not require any new logic to be implemented in software. The typical ARM 64 load and store instructions have new circuitry hard-coded in these latest ARM CPUs, which validates the pointer and memory tags almost instantly with no noticeable performance overhead.

So, in practice, how would this prevent exploitation? For typical use after freeing bugs, a program mistakenly uses a pointer to already freed memory.

But with MIE enabled, as soon as a memory access is made, the ARM hardware will recognize the tag mismatch and trigger an exception. Similarly, for buffer overflows, the very first out-of-bounds write will fail due to the address and memory tag mismatch.

One small caveat is that since these memory tags are only four bits, separate allocations can have the same tag, but this still provides a strong defence since the reliability of an exploit will drop to a 1 in 16 chance of success.

Protection vs performance

With all that power built into the hardware, you are probably wondering, why is MIE not enabled everywhere on iOS. It comes down to a choice between protection and performance, which are defined by the two modes in which MTE operates.

MTE comes in two modes, synchronous and asynchronous.

Synchronous mode is optimized for protection over performance, and it is the only mode the Android open-source project claims can act as a true security mitigation.

Asynchronous mode offers higher performance but does not necessarily crash the application immediately, and it does not record some information about the memory that is being improperly accessed.

If you look at how MTE is used in GrapheneOS, for example, they enable MTE on the kernel in synchronous mode.

But for userland apps, they use a hybrid approach where they use synchronous mode when apps are writing to memory, but they use asynchronous mode when apps are reading from memory.

And the Android open-source project refers to this as asymmetric mode. They claim that this provides a balance, but it is still not as robust as purely operating in synchronous mode.

iOS, on the other hand, uses synchronous mode exclusively in all the areas where it uses MIE.

According to Apple, in asynchronous mode, memory corruption does not instantly trigger an exception, which may result in a period during which exploitation is possible.

Even though Apple has made synchronous MTE more efficient thanks to the new hardware, the performance impact of enabling it is why they have enabled it selectively.

MTE also makes existing memory safety bugs much more visible to users. The likelihood that an existing bug causes an app crash increases when MTE is enabled.

For this reason, many would probably be unlikely to put up with broadly enabled MTE across the entire system right now.

But hopefully, this becomes less of an issue over time as developers improve their apps thanks to this new debugging ability.

Why this new feature matters

Getting back to cybersecurity on mobile devices, all of this is of particular relevance to people who are being targeted by mercenary spyware like Pegasus.

Attackers rarely use a single exploit; they chain many smaller exploits together.

If an attacker gains even a limited access through a vulnerable application, they can leverage that privilege to compromise additional applications, potentially reaching the highest levels of your operating system.

Since the majority of problems are memory-related, many of the links in these chains are memory corruption bugs—bugs which could potentially be stopped by MTE.

As Apple puts it, "inevitably, attackers must face memory integrity enforcement at a stage where their capabilities are still very limited, leaving very few viable avenues for exploitation." Breaking just one step invalidates the entire attack strategy.

The protections MIE gives against malware and spyware that rely on these exploit chains are enormous because they dramatically reduce the probability of a successful chain of attacks.

On Apple's own research blog, they state that they believe memory integrity enforcement represents the most significant upgrade to memory safety in the history of consumer operating systems and that even with substantial effort, their internal research team could not rebuild any of their sample exploit chains to work around this mitigation on iOS.

As an iPhone user, this should be a very comforting statement, and for the hacker community, it presents a daunting challenge.

MIE vs. Lockdown Mode

So, how does this compare to lockdown mode?

Lockdown mode is very effective at preventing exploit chains, just like MTE is. But the approach that it takes is very different.

Ultimately, what lockdown mode is doing is reducing your attack surface dramatically by disabling apps and features that you are unlikely to need in the name of security.

If there were an exploit in the iMessage link preview generator, it could now be blocked by MIE, and it would happen without needing to disable link previews because MIE is always enabled.

If MIE blocks an exploit attack, it is detected immediately. MIE crashes the exploited app and logs the details, making it more likely you will receive a threat notification quickly.

If an exploit is blocked simply because you didn’t use link previews, that could be harder to spot after the fact.

For the highest levels of security, these features should be working in tandem.

That is the basics of defence in depth to dramatically reduce the likelihood of an exploit.

I hope Apple soon introduces a feature that lets Lockdown Mode enable MTE system-wide for both the OS and apps.

As I mentioned earlier, MTE is only enabled selectively outside the kernel on iOS for both performance and stability reasons.

Lockdown Mode users are far more likely to accept app crashes and performance drawbacks for improved security. If they added per-app toggles like GrapheneOS, where you could decide which apps this gets enabled on or not, that would be even better for these advanced users with very high-risk threat models.

This is a massive leap forward in terms of security for iPhone users, and frankly, it is the first time in a long while that I have been genuinely thrilled about an Apple product.

While MTE is a hardware feature that is exclusive to the iPhone 17 series, some of the other improvements that Apple includes in MIE are implemented in iOS 26, and they will be accessible to older devices.

The other thing is that most casual users aren't exploited by Pegasus. However, the likelihood that you could face a threat like mercenary or commercial spyware should not be understated.

If your work puts a target on your back—MIE is not a feature; it is an insurance policy that considerably raises the bar on your personal security posture.

Take a moment to breathe on that. Your digital safety just got a massive upgrade.

The writer is a contributor and a tech enthusiast.

title: 3 golden rules for buying an AMD motherboard in 2026
body:
Choosing an AMD motherboard—especially with the incredible performance of the latest Ryzen CPUs—is the foundation of any great build.

But when selecting an AMD motherboard, you are really answering one core question: "What am I planning to do with my PC over the next five years?"

If you paused and took a moment to breathe after that question, you are on the right track.

Your board must be able to support your specific components and workflow — not just today, but for years to come.

Let's cut through the marketing noise, shall we?

Rule 1: All about the socket

This is the non-negotiable step. The socket is the physical slot where your CPU goes.

This is your primary filter when narrowing down motherboard options.

Right now, AMD gives you two main choices, and one is the clear winner for your money.

As AM6 approaches, AM5 remains the current-generation standard. It supports all the fastest Ryzen CPUs like the 7000, 8000, and 9000 series, along with DDR5 memory, providing higher bandwidth and lower latency for demanding workloads.

The motherboard and DDR5 RAM initially cost more. At Computex 2024, AMD announced support for the platform until 2027 and beyond.

This means any AM5 motherboard you purchase now will still be relevant for future AMD CPU launches, without the need to buy a new motherboard. You pay more now, save later.

AM4 is the budget champion. Supports older, but still great, CPUs like the Ryzen 5000 series and still cheaper DDR4 RAM. AM4 is a legacy platform—still capable but nearing its sunset.

But, if you buy AM4 today, you will have to replace the entire motherboard (and RAM!) the next time you want a major CPU upgrade.

Only choose this if your budget is absolutely hit rock bottom.

If you can stretch the budget for one component, make it an AM5 motherboard. It’s the gatekeeper to all future performance.

Rule 2: Selecting the right chipset

The chipset is the motherboard’s control centre.

This is what enables advanced features like blazing-fast SSD, CPU overclocking, and high-speed connectivity. While all AM5 chipsets share the same powerful foundation, they differ in how much “infrastructure” they offer—from PCIe lanes to USB bandwidth.

And here is the truth: paying more does not always mean you get the best deal.

You are choosing between three main types; each tailored for a different kind of user.

Once you understand what each tier unlocks, the decision becomes surprisingly simple.

X-Series: Luxury overkill

This is the neighbourhood where prices start to make your eyes water. You only need to be here if your PC is your full-time job or your identity.

At the top, you have the X870E and X670E, the “Maxed Out” Elite. These dual-chipset boards deliver everything: the highest port count, multiple USB 4.0 connections, and massive bandwidth.

These boards have the most robust, highest-phase-count VRMs to support extreme overclocking and the highest-end CPUs under sustained load.

If you are planning to run everything at ultra-pro-max—and you have the budget to match—this is your playground. But for 99% of people, it’s overkill.

Just below that sit the X870 and X670, the “Prosumer” class. They offer nearly all the bells and whistles of their “E” counterparts, with slightly reduced connectivity.

These boards are ideal for high-end gamers and content creators who want serious overclocking headroom and more than just a couple of fast ports.

B-Series: King of the hill

The B-Series chipset tier delivers the speed and features you can actually feel. It is the chipset that balances performance, price, and future-readiness like no other.

At the centre is the B850 chipset, the new benchmark for mainstream excellence.

It offers all the essentials: CPU overclocking for manual tuning, PCIe 5.0 lanes for your GPU and M.2 SSDs, and a generous spread of USB ports.

It lets you build a powerful, future-proof PC at a truly reasonable price. And the money you save can go toward a better GPU, cooler, or PSU.

Meanwhile, the B650 and B650E represent the previous generation’s crown.

The B650E guarantees PCIe 5.0 for your GPU slot, while the regular B650 is still capable—but the B650 chipset has reached its end of life.

They are similar to the B850 in many ways but often lack newer I/O standards like Wi-Fi 7 or consistent 20Gbps USB ports.

The B650 chipset will be discontinued in the market once existing inventory from motherboard manufacturers is sold.

Bottom line? If you find a great deal on a B650 board, it is still a solid pick. But for a new build, the B850 is the smarter choice, especially with Zen 5 support baked in.

B840 & A620: Basics Only

If your goal is simply to build the cheapest PC that powers on, this is where you land. But be prepared to sacrifice key features.

B840 and A620 are entry-level chipsets designed for bare-minimum functionality.

You lose CPU overclocking, and more critically, you miss out on PCIe 5.0 speeds—both for your GPU and your primary SSD slot. Fast USB ports? Also absent.

These boards are only worth considering if you are building a basic office PC, a computer for a student, where price is the only factor.

For serious gaming (do not fall for any scam) or productivity, steer clear.

You will hit performance roadblocks in no time, and upgrading later will likely mean replacing the entire system.

Rule 3: Don't skimp on the essential features

Once you have chosen your chipset, the next step is to examine the motherboard’s individual features.

This is where the real difference between an average build and a great one begins to emerge.

Power, Stability, and Cooling:Voltage Regulator Modules (VRMs) act as precision power converters, transforming the 12V from your power supply into the ultra-low voltage (typically between 1.0 and 1.4 volts) required by your CPU cores, all while managing intense current demands.

The effectiveness of VRM depends on two key factors: phase count and amperage rating.

Phase count determines how evenly electrical load and heat are distributed across the board. More phases generally mean better thermal balance and improved stability under load.

Amperage rating, on the other hand, reflects the quality of the individual components—the higher the rating, the more power each phase can handle before overheating. That is why always check both phase count and amperage together.

The quality and phase count of the VRMs are directly related to the chipset tier. X870E/ X670E boards have 18+ phases of the highest quality (up to 110A per stage) to handle unlocked high-core CPUs under extreme stress.

In contrast, entry-level boards like the A620 come with minimal VRM, which limits their ability to support sustained high-performance tasks.

Also note that VRMs generate significant heat, and without proper cooling, performance suffers. It is the difference between peak performance and silent throttling.

Beyond power delivery, a well-designed BIOS makes it easy to tune RAM profiles, adjust fan curves, and troubleshoot issues.

Onboard diagnostic LEDs (CPU, DRAM, VGA, BOOT) are invaluable—they pinpoint issues instantly if your system fails to boot.

These small features save hours of guesswork and frustration and make a big difference in user experience.

Expansion, connectivity, and audio:When evaluating a motherboard, start with the PCIe expansion slots—they house your GPU and other expansion cards.

The chipset determines how many PCIe lanes you get and what generation they support (like PCIe 4.0 vs. 5.0), which directly impacts bandwidth.

Memory compatibility is equally crucial: check whether the board supports DDR4 or DDR5, and what speeds it can handle.

Buying high-frequency RAM is pointless if your motherboard’s memory controller can’t keep up—especially with AMD’s EXPO profiles, where tighter tuning can unlock real-world gains.

Rear I/O and internal headers shape your daily experience: how many USB ports do you need? Do you need USB-C for fast charging or high-speed data? Are there enough fan headers for your cooling setup?

Finally, do not overlook onboard audio.

While discrete sound cards exist, a premium onboard chip like the Realtek ALC1220P or 4080—paired with shielded circuitry and quality capacitors—can deliver clean, immersive sound without interference.

Long-term value & support:Build quality matters more than most people realize. A solid motherboard with a thick PCB and reinforced PCIe slots is less likely to bend or crack, especially when supporting heavy GPUs.

Premium features like onboard power/reset buttons and metal shielding not only enhance durability but also make the build more satisfying.

Beyond hardware, the vendor’s ecosystem plays a crucial role.

Reliable brands like Asus, MSI, Gigabyte, and ASRock offer stable BIOS updates, functional control software for RGB and fan tuning, and dependable driver support.

Good customer support is priceless when something goes wrong.So do not just chase the lowest price—consider long-term value.

A slightly more expensive board with better VRMs and a newer chipset could save you from costly upgrades or a full rebuild down the line.

Are We Paying “Asus Tax”

Now, let's talk about the motherboard market of Bangladesh.

You have got to ask yourself: am I buying a motherboard, or a logo? This is where the story gets really interesting, and honestly, a little frustrating.

Take the two titans of the industry, MSI and Asus, for example.

Both brands offer motherboards with nearly identical core specs and VRM designs. Yet, time and again, the Asus boards typically demand a premium over their MSI counterparts.

Take the mid-range sweet spot, for example, from the house of MSI: MAG B850M MORTAR and MAG B850 Tomahawk Max, versus from the house of Asus: ROG Strix B850-G and ROG Strix B850-A.

All these boards run the B850 chipset and offer almost similar specs.

But if you compare apples to apples, you will see both MSI boards come with a Realtek (8126-VB) 5G LAN and full-bandwidth Wi-Fi 7 (320MHz) offer double the wireless throughput (up to 5.8Gbps!) and faster wired performance compared to Asus’s older Intel 2.5G LAN and halved Wi-Fi 7 bandwidth.

Which industry reports often cite the Realtek 5G chip as providing better stability and fewer driver issues than the Intel 2.5G version—a critical factor for long-term reliability. Yet, you are paying 5,000 taka more for the Asus Strix (38,500 vs 33,500).

Remember, LAN is not just about the internet—it is your internal expressway for file transfers, backups, media streaming, and real-time collaboration.

Look at the display output: the MSI boards support HDMI 2.1 FLR, capable of pushing 8K at 60Hz. Asus boards, by contrast, top out at 4K at 60Hz via HDMI 2.1. Asus appears to be limiting bandwidth on this tier.

On the overclocking front, the ATX models illustrate the point perfectly.

The MSI Tomahawk Max has a better theoretical maximum memory speed of 8400 MT/s (OC) compared to the Asus Strix B850-A's 8000 MT/s (OC).

Both have virtually identical high-end VRMs (14+2+1 vs. 14+2+2, both 80A SPS), but MSI is still 4,500 Taka cheaper (38,500 vs. 43,000).

That saved 4,500–5,000 Taka is not just sitting in your wallet—it’s buying you an essential upgrade: a faster SSD, a better CPU cooler, a more reliable PSU, or even a nice dinner out.

So, ask yourself again: is your build driving the brand, or is the brand driving your build?

MSI is doing something incredible: delivering premium design with aesthetics, rock-solid boards with feature sets without forcing you to pay a brand tax.

I am not saying go get every MSI and ditch Asus. I am just telling you, do your need assessment, choose your chipset, compare the board specifications, look at the price tag and then make your investment decision.

A fanboy attitude will not earn you anything, but a smart choice will surely do.

Focus on these three rules, and you will walk away with a motherboard that is smarter, more reliable, and a far better long-term deal.

Your future self (and your wallet) will thank you for being a wise buyer.

The writer is a contributor and a tech enthusiast.

title: From Khichuri to Pitha: The foods that make winter comforting
body:
Winter does not just arrive with a change in weather, it reshapes our memories around food.

Comfort food in winter is deeply emotional. In Bangladesh, winter comfort food has a character of its own. Seasonal vegetables like cauliflower, cabbage, carrots, peas and beans dominate home kitchens.

Simple yet satisfying dishes such as mixed vegetables, khichuri, and pitha become staples.

Here are some of the most common winter foods that we find in most homes and streets of the country during winter.

Khichuri is one of Bangladesh’s most beloved winter comfort foods. Made by cooking rice and lentils with seasonal vegetables and spices, it becomes especially popular during the colder months when the body craves hearty, filling meals.

Winter khichuri — often prepared as bhuna khichuri — is richer and more flavourful, commonly served with beef or chicken curry, fried eggplant, pickles, and green chilli.

Winter is the season of pitha. These traditional rice cakes are more than just food; they are symbols of celebration and togetherness. From bhapa pitha and chitoy pitha to patishapta filled with coconut and jaggery, pithas bring sweetness and warmth to winter evenings. Often enjoyed with cups of steaming tea, they turn ordinary gatherings into beautiful moments.

Mixed vegetable is a staple winter dish in Bangladesh, made with a colourful combination of seasonal vegetables such as cauliflower, cabbage, carrot, beans, peas, and potatoes.

Often served with rice or roti, mixed vegetable is valued for its balance of flavour and health, making it an everyday favourite in Bangladeshi households during the winter months.

Tea is a favourite in Bangladesh and an essential winter comfort. From roadside stalls to household kitchens, steaming cups of milk tea, spiced tea, or lemon tea are a common sight during the winter months.

Beyond warmth, tea serves as a social ritual — paired with snacks like pitha or biscuits — making it a beautiful part of Bangladeshi winter culture.

title: Pitha season: Why winter feels incomplete without it
body:
In Bangladesh, winter doesn’t really arrive with numbers on a weather app. It shows up in quieter ways -- when rice flour is soaking in the kitchen, when someone mentions khejur gur, when pitha becomes a topic of conversation again. Without pitha, winter feels… unfinished.

Pitha is not just food. It’s a seasonal habit. Once winter sets in, kitchens slow down a little. Measurements become approximate, recipes become memories.

Someone always corrects someone else, and somehow the pitha still turns out fine. That part never changes.

What ties pitha so closely to winter is how dependent it is on the season itself. Fresh date palm jaggery, rice, cool evenings—these are not things you can fully recreate at any other time of year. Yes, pitha can be made anytime, but it onlybelongsto winter.

There’s also something deeply social about it. Pitha is rarely made for one person. It gathers people around the stove. Mothers, aunts, neighbours, each doing something small but necessary. The food takes time, and so do the conversations.

Winter mornings with leftover pitha, slightly reheated and eaten with tea or milk, have a comfort that’s hard to explain. Even street-side pitha in the city carries a trace of nostalgia. It reminds people of courtyards, villages, and winters that felt colder than they probably were.

The season passes quickly. The cold fades, khejur gur disappears, and kitchens return to their usual rhythm.

That’s why pitha matters. It marks winter while it lasts. Without it, the season doesn’t feel complete.

title: Pakistan moves toward a smoke-free future as demand for modern alternatives rises
body:
Pakistan is rapidly expandingitsmarket for smokeless, tobacco-free nicotine pouches, a development that is expected to change addiction patterns in the second-largest nation in South Asia.

Some public health and industry players contend that this change could lessen the negative effects of smoking while creating new business and regulatory opportunities.

The government of Pakistan has started to focus more on healthier,less harmfulalternatives for adult smokers, as the country’s smokeless-pouch market continues to mature.

As part of this shift, Philip Morris (Pakistan) Limited (PMPKL) hasrecentlybegun local production of its tobacco-free pouch brand, ZYN, at its Sahiwal facilitya move announced in November 2025 to expand access to "combustion-free"options.

Company officials note that while these products are not risk-free and remain addictive, they may offer a better choice for adults who would otherwise continue to smoke.

Pakistan’s early momentum in this category began with British American

Tobacco’s Pakistan Tobacco Company (PTC), which introducedVeloin 2019 and helped establish a sizeable and fast-growing consumer base for modern oral smoking alternatives in the country.

With a population of over 247 million, Pakistan remains among the world’s major tobacco-consuming countries: roughly 19.5% of adults use tobacco in some form, with as many as 32% of males reportedly current users.

Meanwhile, traditional oral tobacco products such aspaan,naswar, andgutkacontinue to account for a significant portion of consumption, especially among lower-income groups.

But the market is changing.

Since 2019, the smokeless product segment in Pakistan has grown rapidly, spearheaded by the launch of nicotine pouches by leading tobacco industry players.

Arecentcase study on smokeless goods in Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs) claims that Pakistan has the world's largest consumer base for oral nicotine pouches due to adult tobacco users searching for alternatives to traditional chewable tobacco or cigarettes.

The study shows notable differences in toxicant levels between modern nicotine pouches and traditional oral tobacco products: In terms of significant carcinogens like lead, arsenic, cadmium, and tobacco-specific nitrosamines, nicotine pouches are purportedly "many-fold"lower thannaswarorgutka.

Smokeless product advocates argue that this is a significant chance to reduce harm.

With Pakistan's high incidence of oral cavity cancer and other tobacco-related illnesses, switching from combustible, uncontrolled oral tobacco to cleaner, regulated nicotine pouches may eventually lessen the burden on public health.

The shift toward controlled, smokeless nicotine products is being positioned as an alternative for adult tobacco users unable or unwilling to quit, offering a modest but meaningful reduction in exposure to the toxicants found in smoked and traditional oral tobacco.

At the same time, local production is creating new economic value through jobs, tax revenue and improved oversight that can curb illicit trade.

As this market evolves, policymakers will need to balance harm-reduction potential with strict regulation, age controls, and ongoing monitoring, even as companies like BAT and PMPKL present these products as steps toward a healthier future.

As Pakistan advances its shift toward regulated, lower-toxicant alternatives, the developments offer timely insights for Bangladesh, where tobacco use remains high and public-health costs continue to rise.

Pakistan’s experience highlights how structured regulation, safer options for adult smokers, and local manufacturing can work together to reduce harm while strengthening oversight.

As Bangladesh reviews its own tobacco-control framework, these regional lessons may help shape a more balanced, health-focused path forward.

title: Cracked heels in winter: causes, care and remedies
body:
With winter comes a common yet often uncomfortable problem for many — cracked heels. The condition may start with mild roughness, but in severe cases, cracks can deepen, sometimes causing bleeding. The pain while walking, loss of appearance, and risk of infection make cracked heels more than a cosmetic concern; they are a genuine health issue. With a little care and regular maintenance, however, cracked heels can be effectively managed.

The primary cause of cracked heels is excessive dryness of the skin. Cold, dry winter air, insufficient water intake, wearing open sandals, prolonged exposure to water, frequent use of soap, vitamin deficiencies, and conditions such as diabetes can all increase the risk. Often, the skin on the feet becomes so dry and thick that the pressure from walking causes it to split.

The first and most crucial step toward relief is regular foot care. Soaking the feet in lukewarm water for 10–15 minutes every night helps soften the skin. Adding a little salt or liquid soap can enhance the effect. After soaking, gently remove dead skin with a pumice stone or foot file — lightly, not harshly — then pat the feet dry.

Moisturizing is the next essential step. Apply a good-quality moisturizer, glycerine, petroleum jelly, or foot cream thoroughly, especially on cracked areas. Wearing cotton socks afterwards allows the cream to work overnight. Regular care over a few days can significantly reduce cracking.

Several natural remedies also provide relief. Massaging pure coconut or mustard oil into the feet nightly reduces dryness. Honey acts as a natural moisturizer; applying it to the heels for 20 minutes before rinsing helps soften the skin. A scrub made from rice flour, honey, and a little milk can be used once or twice a week to remove dead skin. Aloe vera gel is another effective natural treatment.

Caring for the skin internally is as important as external treatment. Drinking sufficient water daily helps prevent dryness, and a diet rich in vitamins A, C, E, and zinc — including carrots, oranges, lemons, nuts, leafy vegetables, and eggs — supports healthy skin. For people with diabetes, maintaining proper blood sugar levels is crucial, as cracked heels can become infected more easily.

A few precautions can help prevent cracked heels. Avoid wearing very hard or open sandals for long periods. Apply moisturizer after bathing or before bed. Also, avoid soaking the feet in excessively hot water for too long, as this can worsen dryness.

If cracks become deep, cause bleeding, severe pain, pus, or show any signs of infection, it is safer to consult a specialist rather than rely solely on home remedies. Without timely care, even simple cracked heels can lead to complications.

With awareness, regular care, and healthy habits, this painful winter problem can be managed easily. In colder months, paying attention not just to the face and hands but also to the feet ensures comfort and overall well-being.

title: Student Ways and Borshadupur: 75 years of Bengali publishing with a global presence
body:
Bengali literature has long been shaped by publishers who combine vision, responsibility, and cultural commitment. Among such institutions, Student Ways holds a distinguished place. Founded by Alhaj Mohammad Habibullah, Student Ways established itself as a trusted platform for serious literary, educational, and intellectual works, playing a vital role in the growth of Bengali publishing in Bangladesh.

Building on this strong foundation, Mohammad Mashfiqullah Tonmoy, the current owner and CEO, later founded Borshadupur with a forward-looking vision. While Student Ways represents literary heritage and classical depth, Borshadupur reflects a modern publishing philosophy, resonating strongly with contemporary readers and younger generations.

In the digital age, both publishing houses continue to operate successfully through a structured and professional approach. Manuscript selection and book release decisions are handled by specialized editorial and review teams, ensuring quality, relevance, and consistency across all publications. This disciplined process has played a key role in sustaining their long-term success.

With a publishing legacy spanning over 75 years, Student Ways and Borshadupur have collectively published more than 5,000 books across a wide range of genres and subjects. Their catalog includes novels, short stories, poetry, essays, literary criticism, books on the Liberation War, social and cultural studies, history, travelogues, medicine, biography, music, juvenile literature, technology-related works, and reference books.

The contribution of Student Ways to Bengali literature has been recognized through numerous prestigious awards, including the Adamjee Literary Award, Dawood Literary Award, 6th September Award, National Book Centre Award, Alaol Literary Award, and the Shishu Academy Award, reflecting decades of literary excellence.

Beyond the domestic market, these publishing houses have established a growing international presence. Their books are sold worldwide through major book fairs and global distribution channels. Recently, they have also begun listing and selling their books on Amazon, expanding access for international readers and opening new avenues for global reach alongside traditional book fair sales.

Student Ways and Borshadupur have actively participated in major national and international book fairs, including the Frankfurt Book Fair, Liber International Book Fair in Madrid, Asian Festival of Children’s Content in Singapore, Muktodhara Book Fair in New York, Kuala Lumpur International Book Fair in Malaysia, Bangkok International Book Fair in Thailand, FOBANA in Atlanta, Kolkata Book Fair, Agartala Book Fair, Guwahati Book Fair, Silchar Book Fair, Assam Book Fair, and the Delhi International Book Fair.

Rooted in tradition yet responsive to change, Student Ways and Borshadupur continue to publish with confidence and success. Through professional editorial practices, digital expansion, and international distribution, they remain committed to carrying Bengali literature from Bangladesh to readers around the world.

title: Netflix to buy Warner Bros for 72 billion dollars
body:
Netflix on Friday announced a landmark agreement to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery’s studio and streaming operations for 72 billion dollars, a move that would unite two of the biggest names in global entertainment.

Under the deal, Netflix would take over Warner’s flagship film and television units, along with HBO Max and DC Studios. Netflix, already a dominant force in on-demand viewing with hits like “Stranger Things” and “Squid Game,” has steadily expanded its own production capabilities in recent years, reports UNB.

The cash-and-stock offer values Warner at 27.75 dollars per share, setting its total enterprise value at about 82.7 billion dollars. The transaction is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2026, after Warner spins off its Discovery Global cable networks into a separate publicly traded company.

title: HM Alvee wins US hackathon with EnigmaKeep, an offline password manager
body:
Bangladeshi tech innovator HM Alvee Hasan, a cybersecurity student studying in the United States, has won a US university-level hackathon for developing EnigmaKeep, an offline password manager designed to put user privacy first. The project has gained attention for its clean design, strong encryption, and open-source structure, offering users a safer and more transparent way to protect their digital data.

EnigmaKeep was developed while Alvee was pursuing his degree in IT-Cybersecurity and Network Administration. His main goal was to create a secure system that doesn’t rely on the cloud. Unlike popular password managers such as Bitwarden or LastPass, EnigmaKeep stores all credentials directly on the user’s device, keeping them safe from online breaches and server leaks.

The software uses AES-256-GCM encryption and PBKDF2 key derivation with 600,000 iterations, providing the same level of protection used by major financial institutions. It also includes biometric authentication for fingerprint and Face ID login and functions as a Progressive Web App (PWA), making it accessible on any device without needing an internet connection.

“I wanted to create something that gives people complete control over their data,” said HM Alvee. “Most password managers depend on cloud storage, but privacy should never require trust in a third party.”

He added, “EnigmaKeep is built to be fully offline so users can have total confidence that their information stays only with them. That’s what true digital privacy means.”

These features make EnigmaKeep a powerful option for individuals and professionals who value security but prefer not to depend on cloud services or paid subscriptions.

EnigmaKeep is completely free and open-source, released under the MIT License on GitHub. This transparency allows developers around the world to inspect, audit, and contribute to the project.

“Cybersecurity should be available to everyone,” said Alvee. “You shouldn’t have to pay a company or rely on a server to keep your passwords safe. Open-source projects like EnigmaKeep prove that privacy and accessibility can go hand in hand.”

Alvee’s success highlights the growing influence of Bangladeshi innovators in international technology. His work on EnigmaKeep reflects a growing movement toward privacy-first software, at a time when data protection has become a global concern.

Professors and peers in the US have praised the project for its ethical approach and technical quality, describing it as an example of how cybersecurity tools should be built — secure, transparent, and user-controlled.

“Winning the hackathon was an incredible moment,” Alvee said. “It showed that meaningful innovation can come from anywhere, and that Bangladeshi students can compete globally in technology and cybersecurity.”

EnigmaKeep is a zero-knowledge, offline password manager that secures user data through advanced encryption and biometric access. It runs on all major devices, functions entirely offline, and supports importing and exporting data from leading password management platforms.

Website: https://enigmakeep.com

GitHub: https://github.com/hmalvee/EnigmaKeep

title: History of the beginning Bangla newspapers
body:
The beginning of publishing newspapers in Bangla was not just a journey of providing news; it was the beginning of a social change. More than two centuries ago, when the educated population in the subcontinent was very limited, the Bangla newspaper was born. Its journey began with courage, a confident outlook, and ideals. Which serves as an inspiration forall Bangla newspapertoday.

Around 1818, under the patronage of Raja Rammohan Roy and edited by Gangakishore Bhattacharya, the first Bangla newspaper, "Bengal Gazette," started its journey. According to Brajendranath Bandyopadhyay, it was first published between 14th May and 9th July, and its existence can be found in the writings of Bhawanicharan Banerjee, Ishwar Chandra Gupta, and others. The newspaper was published for a year, but no printed or handwritten copy of it has been found.

On 23rd May 1818, the newspaper 'Samachar Darpan' was published from the Serampore Missionary Center in West Bengal. Many experts and researchers recognize it as the first Bangla language newspaper. John Clark Marshman was the editor of the newspaper. On 25 December 1841, Samachar Darpan was closed forever.

After this start, some other Bangla newspapers were published quickly. In 1822, the conservative Hindu community newspaper "Samachar Chandrika" was published; its editor was Bhuvanmohan Mukherjee. In 1829, "Sambad Bhaskar," representing social reformist and secular thought, was published. In 1843, the newspaper "Tattvabodhini" was published; its editor was Debendranath Tagore.

At this time, setting up a printing press and making printing letters was a big challenge in Bangla. Printing technology in Bangla script was established through William Carey and the Serampore Mission. This made the publication and distribution of newspapers easier.

The first newspaper in Bangladesh (then East Bengal) was 'Dharmattav,' published in 1848 from Dhaka, a monthly newspaper. According to many historians, it was the first significant printed publication published in East Bengal. However, it was a religious newspaper. However, the first Bangla language newspaper published in this region for the purpose of publishing regular news was "Dhaka Prakash," published in 1861; its publisher was Radharman Ghosh.

In present-day Bangladesh, or in the former East Pakistan in 1971, several powerful newspapers were established, the most notable of which were Dainik Azad (published in Dhaka: 1948), Dainik Ittefaq (first issue: 1949), and Dainik Sangbad (published in 1951).

After Bangladesh gained independence through the Great Liberation War in 1971, several notable newspapers were Dainik Bangla, Dainik Ittefaq, Dainik Sangbad, Dainik Janapada, Ganakanth, Sangbadpatra, etc.

Since the 90s, several other popular and reputable newspapers have been established in Bangladesh, including Prothom Alo, Janakantha, Kaler Kantha, Jugantor, etc. All these newspapers have initiated a new trend of investigative journalism.

Currently, newspapers in this digital age have gone beyond printed paper and reached the reader's mobile screen through the Internet; these are called online news portals, which are basically the modern version of newspapers. The first online news portal of Bangladesh, bdnews24.com, started its journey in 2005. Apart from this, there are several other popular online news portals in Bangladesh at present.

The history of Bangla newspapers is not only the history of news reporting; it is the history of our identity, protest, reform, and change. Newspapers, this entire journey, starting from the Bengal Gazette to today's mobile screen, are the holders and carriers of our language, culture, and consciousness. Bangla newspapers are not only the past; they are the guide to the future.

title: Mohammad Rafique brings Bengali romance to life through soulful new duets
body:
Independent singer-songwriter Mohammad Rafique is steadily emerging as a profound new voice in Bengali music, and his latest romantic release “Achho Tumi” — a duet with national award-winning vocalist Nancy — marks a significant milestone in his evolving discography.

His music, known for its minimalistic acoustic and electronic arrangements, prioritizes storytelling over trends, building a loyal following among listeners who crave sincerity in sound.

With NextBeat Entertainment supporting his independent vision and high-quality production values, and with successful collaborations with a celebrated figure like Nancy, Mohammad Rafique is proving that emotionally rich, independent Bengali music has a powerful place in today’s landscape.

body:
For the first time in Bangladesh’s history, books written by a digital content creator have made it to multiple prestigious international book fairs.

Two best-selling titles by acclaimed Bangladeshi content creator RobinRafan are now being featured at the Pesta Buku Antarabangsa Kuala Lumpur 2025 (Kuala Lumpur International Book Fair), held at the World Trade Center, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

The fair runs from May 23 to June 1, and the books are available at Mind to Mind Publication’s Stall (S9-13).

The two featured books—”Creative Content O Safal Career” and “Vobisshot er Freelancing: Proshikkhon Theke Safollo”—have become household names among aspiring content creators and freelancers across Bangladesh. Originally published by Borshadupur / Studentways Publications, both titles have earned bestseller status and are now reaching international readers.

This global milestone follows successful participation at the 34th International Bangla Book Fair in New York, hosted by the Muktodhara Foundation, where readers from the Bangladeshi diaspora enthusiastically collected signed copies. Just days earlier, the same books were featured at the Asian Festival of Children’s Content and Book Fair 2025 in Singapore from May 22 to 25.

According to the CEO of Borshadupur Publications, “Due to the global fanbase of content creator RobinRafan, we made the decision to send these titles to international book fairs. The response has been unbelievable—this marks a new chapter for Bangladeshi creators on the global stage.”

RobinRafan, professionally known as Obidur Rahman, is a digital pioneer in Bangladesh, recognized for his work as a content creator, author, and Educator. He is the founder of RobinRafan Academy, a platform that has trained over 3,000 content creators globally through AI and creative media masterclasses. Known for blending storytelling with technology, RobinRafan has made a profound impact on young creators both in Bangladesh and abroad.

His books reflect years of experience, offering practical guidance on digital content strategies, freelancing ethics, monetization, and platform-based growth. The international recognition of his work stands as a testament to the rising influence of Bangladeshi creators in the global creative economy.

About this success, RobinRafan said”My biggest strength is my followers around the world. Their love for my content and constant support inspire me every day. I’m committed to working even harder to help nurture and empower more creative content creators globally. That is my new dream.”

As RobinRafan’s journey continues to inspire creators across borders, his voice is no longer just a digital presence—it’s a global movement for creativity, empowerment, and innovation. With each milestone, he redefines what it means to be a Bangladeshi content creator on the world stage.

title: Young entrepreneur Sabbin Islam Sanan honored with ‘Excellence in Success Award 2025’
body:
Sabbin Islam Sanan, a 24-year-old Bangladeshi entrepreneur and the managing director of Tawakkul Malaysia Education Consultancy, has been awarded the prestigious “Excellence in Success Award 2025” in the category of Young Entrepreneur of the Year.

The award was presented to Sanan by the chief guest of the ceremony, senior advocate of the Bangladesh Supreme Court and Vice Chairman of the BNP, Zainul Abedin.

The event was further graced by distinguished personalities including celebrated actress Dilara Zaman, National Film Award-winning actress Runa Khan, former Additional Secretary Pirzada Shahidul Harun, Additional DIG Md Apel Mahmud, and other prominent figures from diverse sectors.

The event was jointly organized by World of Unity and Greenleaf Foundation, with ETV serving as the media partner.

Speaking on the occasion, Sanan said: “This recognition is not just an award to me—it’s an inspiration to continue serving students who dream of studying abroad. I am honored and motivated to work even harder for the betterment of international education access for Bangladeshi youth.”

At such a young age, Sanan has successfully enrolled over 700 students into reputable Malaysian universities.

His consultancy firm offers end-to-end services including visa processing, university admission, accommodation arrangements, and airport pickup facilities.

His achievement not only highlights his personal success but also underscores the growing impact of Bangladeshi youth in the global education sector.

title: RobinRafan completes AI Masterclass Season 4 with more than 830 global participants
body:
Renowned Bangladeshi content creator, AI educator, and digital innovator RobinRafan, also known as Obidur Rahman, has successfully concluded Season 4 of his internationally followed AI Masterclass for Content Creators, with participation from over 830 creators worldwide.

This highly anticipated season featured learners not only from Bangladesh but also from 15+ countries including the USA, UK, Canada, Singapore, Malaysia, France, Germany, and Italy, reflecting the global impact of RobinRafan’s work. His viral AI and VFX videos have rapidly earned him a massive international following, with many creators requesting specialized training on the tools and techniques behind his content.

Following this fourth installment, RobinRafan has now trained over 3,000 content creators globally through his AI Masterclass series — a record-setting milestone for any Bangladeshi educator in the digital creator space.

The Season 4 curriculum was designed to equip creators with a wide range of advanced AI skills, including Text to Image generation, Image to Video transformation, AI-powered Video to Video editing, and Faceless video animation techniques. Participants also learned how to create Text to Music and full songs, perform Text to Voice conversion, manage multi-element content creation workflows, launch AI-powered YouTube channels, and build their own custom AI model characters — all aimed at empowering content creators to produce high-quality, innovative, and globally competitive content.

These topics were designed to help creators produce high-quality, professional, and globally competitive content using the latest AI tools.

In recognition of his innovation and leadership, RobinRafan was recently honored with the “Best Content Creator of 2025” award at the prestigious 4th BIFA Awards. His ability to teach and inspire content creators across borders continues to set new benchmarks for the creative industry.

RobinRafan said: “To reach the global platform, this kind of AI content is extremely important. If our creators can master these tools, we’ll finally see Bangladeshi content at an international standard — that’s what I aim to achieve.”

Adding to his milestones, RobinRafan has also made history in the literary world. For the first time, books by a Bangladeshi content creator are being officially sold at the New York 34th International Bangla Book Fair, hosted at the Jamaica Performing Arts Center (JPAC). Organized by the Muktodhara Foundation, RobinRafan’s two bestselling books — Creative Content o Safal Career and Vobisshot er Freelancing: Proshikkhon Theke Safollo — are now available for international readers in the Usa International fair., marking a major cultural and professional achievement.

With a rapidly growing global following and a clear mission to blend technology with creativity, RobinRafan is emerging as one of Bangladesh’s most extraordinary digital content creators and AI instructors. The remarkable success of AI Masterclass Season 4 not only underscores his influence in the creator community but also paves the way for even greater international collaborations and innovations in the seasons to come.
