title: RobinRafan’s AI Masterclass season 3 breaks records with 1,000 global content creators
body:
On May 2, Bangladeshi content creator RobinRafan successfully hosted his AI Masterclass for content creators season 3, delivering a live session that spanned nearly four hours.

Following the success of season 1 and season 2, this third season marked a milestone — setting a new record with 1,000 content creators participating in the online workshop, making it one of the largest AI learning events in the creator community.

What made this season particularly notable was its international reach.

Among the 1,000 participants, 50 creators joined from countries such as the USA, UK, France, UAE, South Korea, Spain, Croatia, and more, reflecting RobinRafan’s growing role in global discussions around AI-driven content creation.

The season 3 curriculum was designed as an A-to-Z blueprint for AI integration into a content creator’s workflow, with RobinRafan personally delivering live training on a wide range of advanced techniques.

These included prompt crafting ideas to enhance creativity, text-to-video and faceless video generation for scalable content, image-to-video and text-to-image conversions, image-to-anime transformation, image and video upscaling tools, sound effects and audio improvements, sketch-to-image generation, logo creation through AI, reimagine tools for creative reinterpretation, and text-to-music, text-to-song, and text-to-voice synthesis — shaping new approaches to digital production.

Participants from around the world described the session as a practical and hands-on experience that provided both conceptual understanding and immediately usable skills.

RobinRafan’s body of work extends beyond AI into visual effects (VFX), where he has explored combining these two fields to create visually dynamic, experimental content.

His projects often integrate AI tools with VFX techniques, allowing for unique combinations of automated generation and human-directed design, resulting in multimedia content that blends artificial and practical elements.

Reflecting on this success, RobinRafan said: “For the first time in Bangladesh, as a content creator, I took the step to teach the use of AI in content creation. For Season 3, it was completely unexpected to have 1,000 enrolled content creators. I’m truly grateful to everyone who placed their trust in me.”

He also announced that the AI Masterclass for content creators Season 4 has already been scheduled and will be conducted on May 23 at 10pm globally.

With each season, RobinRafan continues to explore the evolving relationship between technology and content creation, providing insights that reflect the changing landscape of digital media.

title: Springboard 7.0: Young social entrepreneurs recognized for leading the way in innovation and impact
body:
The Springboard 7.0, an event of Youth Co:Lab co-initiated by UNDP and Citi Foundation, and implemented by Impact Hub Dhaka, was successfully held where total of BDT 1,190,000 was awarded to the top three teams Green Dye, Robolife Technologies, and PlanPost AI in recognition of their innovative solutions to tackle the most pressing social and environmental challenges.

A shortlisted group of 9 teams from 177 applicants was invited to the Springboard 7.0 Bootcamp at BRAC Centre for Development Management (BCDM) in Savar, an intensive two-day program designed to sharpen their business strategies and equipping young social entrepreneurs with the skills, mentorship, and connections needed to grow their enterprises. Following the bootcamp, three teams were recognized for their innovation, business potential, and social impact.

The program featured expert-led workshops, networking opportunities, and hands-on pitch training, helping participants refine their business models and develop compelling presentations for investors and stakeholders. The bootcamp focused on key entrepreneurial skills, including refining business ideas, structuring sustainable models, and mastering pitch delivery. Participants received expert mentorship to strengthen their strategies and enhance their readiness for investment.

The program culminated in a Pitch Competition, where teams presented their ventures to a panel of distinguished judges. The competing teams were PlanPost AI, GreenDye, Sundaram, More Tech Bangladesh, Robolife Technologies, Jotner Dokan, TriRE, Sonket, and Nohor IT showcasing innovative solutions across various industries. Rumana Ahmed, Country Public Affairs Officer, Citi Bangladesh; Shaheen Siam, Founding Member & Chief Strategy Officer, Shop Up; Iffat Anjum, Head of Exploration, Accelerator Lab, UNDP; and Waheed R Chaudhuri, Investment Manager, IDLC Venture Capital, were present as judges at the event.

As the Implementing Partner of the 7th Cohort of Youth Co:Lab Springboard Program, Bishwamitra Chowdhury, Director at Impact Hub Dhaka, shared his welcome remarks, emphasizing the significance of empowering young entrepreneurs in shaping the future. He said, “The skills you’ve developed and the networks you’ve built here will be vital as you continue to scale your ventures and contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.”

For the closing remarks, Mahmudul Hasan, Program Manager at UNDP Bangladesh, highlighted the importance of impactful businesses in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and the role of the startup ecosystem in Bangladesh's economy and praised the potential of the ventures showcased this year.

Afruza Tanzi, Innovation and Entrepreneurship Officer at UNDP Bangladesh said, “These innovative startups are not only creating jobs but are also actively contributing to the achievement of the SDGs, helping to build a more sustainable and inclusive future for Bangladesh and beyond. Youth Co:Lab is committed to facilitating the growth of youth-driven startups within the ecosystem.”

Youth Co:Lab, co-created by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and Citi Foundation, empowers young social entrepreneurs across the Asia-Pacific region. Operating in 28 countries and territories, including Bangladesh, the program plays a key role in supporting youth-led innovation and entrepreneurship. Notable graduates from previous cohorts of Youth Co:Lab include MonerBondhu, iFarmer, AmarLab, and GarbageMan, showcasing the program's impact in fostering innovative solutions to social challenges.

For more updates, visit: https://www.youthcolab.org/bangladesh

title: Ashik Khan’s live shopping brings sustainability and affordability together
body:
Sustainability and affordability rarely go hand in hand in the fashion world, but Ashik Khan, a fashion influencer and change-maker, is proving otherwise. Through his innovative demand-based production model, known as the 70/30 Production Model, he is tackling waste management in the Ready-Made Garment (RMG) sector while ensuring premium fashion at affordable prices.

Today, Live Shopping has gained momentum, with nine outlets across Bangladesh and a fast home delivery network nationwide. His production model ensures that fabric waste is minimized, costs are reduced, and workers are treated fairly, making it a groundbreaking shift in the country’s fashion industry.

At the core of this transformation is the 70/30 Production Model, a method that optimizes raw materials and production efficiency. Instead of mass-producing garments without demand, Live Shopping starts with 70% of the available raw materials, keeping 30% in reserve. As demand grows, another 70% is produced from the remaining stock, while 30% is again set aside. This cycle continues, ensuring that materials are never wasted, production costs remain low, and inventory is efficiently managed.

This smart waste management system has allowed Live Shopping to offer high-quality products at unmatched prices. One of its most popular offerings, a premium blazer set, starts at just 2,800 BDT, a price rarely seen for such quality.

Beyond affordability, the cost savings from waste reduction have also enabled Live Shopping to offer better wages and working conditions for employees. This ethical approach sets a new benchmark for Bangladesh’s fashion industry, proving that sustainability can benefit both businesses and workers alike.

However, Ashik Khan's impact extends beyond his brand. As an adjunct faculty member at a reputed private university in Bangladesh he has taught the 70/30 Production Model to over 500 students."Sustainability isn’t just about reducing waste; it’s about building a responsible fashion ecosystem. With our 70/30 Production Model, we’re making premium fashion accessible while ensuring fair treatment of workers and efficient resource management," said Ashik Khan.

From being a software engineer to leading a sustainable fashion revolution, Ashik Khan’s journey is a testament to how innovation, adaptability, and determination can reshape an industry. With a growing number of outlets, an expanding customer base, and a strong commitment to educating future entrepreneurs, Live Shopping is at the forefront of a new era in Bangladesh’s fashion industry. Ashik Khan is not just influencing trends—he’s shaping the future of sustainable fashion and entrepreneurship in Bangladesh.

title: Winter essentials: Must have gadgets and comfort picks
body:
Winter brings chilly winds, shorter days and long nights, transforming how we live, work, and relax. While traditional winter essentials like sweaters, scarves, hot drinks and protective items such as lotion, petroleum jelly, bodyoil remain important, modern gadgets have become indispensable for staying warm, comfortable and connected during the colder months.

Representational image of portable heaters. Photo: Collected

Portable heaters are perfect for warming up quickly or heating a small space. Many come with adjustable heat settings and built-in fans for fast, even warmth. Safety features like automatic shut-off give peace of mind, while compact designs- from desk-sized ceramic heaters to larger living room models, this ensures warmth exactly where you need it.

They are ideal for both home and office use, keeping you comfortable during chilly days.

Representational image of humidifiers. Photo: Collected

Another must-have for winter is the humidifier. Cold weather often brings dry indoor air due to heaters, which can lead to dry skin, throat irritation and respiratory issues.

Modern ultrasonic humidifiers not only maintain optimal humidity levels but also feature smart controls that can be monitored via smartphones. Some models even include essential oil diffusers, adding a soothing fragrance to the home while keeping the air comfortable.

Representational image of cup heaters. Photo: Collected

No one likes a cold cup of coffee or tea. Electric cup warmers keep your drink at the perfect temperature for hours. Sleek and easy to use, most models allow you to adjust the heat to suit your preference, making them ideal for your desk or bedside.

They are compact and portable, so you can easily carry them from room to room. Some models even come with USB connectivity, allowing you to use them with your laptop or power bank. With a cup warmer, every sip stays just the way you like it, adding a touch of comfort to your day.

Representational image of heated blanket. Photo: Collected

For cold winter nights, heated blankets are a cozy must-have. Made from soft fabrics like fleece, they offer adjustable heat levels so you can find your ideal warmth without wasting energy.

Many include automatic shut-off features for safe, worry-free use while sleeping.

Curl up with a book or simply enjoy a warm bed- heated blankets make winter nights truly comfortable. They are perfect for creating a snug, relaxing atmosphere after a long, chilly day.

You can buy these winter gadgets from a variety of stores, including Walton, Transcom Digital, Pickaboo, Gadget & Gear, Daraz or physical outlets in New Market, Bashundhara City and Jamuna Future Park. Prices vary depending on the model, size and features, ranging from Tk1,500 to Tk7,000, making it easy to find something that fits both your needs and budget.

The cold can feel like a foe, but whether you’re working from home or heading out into the crisp air, the right choice of things can provide convenience, protect your health, and enhance the seasonal experience.

title: Is our kitchen making us sick?
body:
We often think foodborne illnesses come from unhygienic street food or expired food items. But a recent study in Dhaka tells a far closer, more surprising story—the real danger might be right inside our kitchens.

Imagine stepping into a typical Dhaka home and inspecting daily kitchen utensils. A recent microbiological test of 100 households revealed shocking results: more than 90% of dish sponges and 81% of bar soap cups were contaminated with E. coli and coliform bacteria. Cutting boards, knives, refrigerator handles, and even stove knobs harbored harmful bacteria. In some cases, these surfaces were as risky as a toilet door handle.

This is not simply a local issue. Globally, research demonstrates a similar pattern: 89% of kitchen towels contain coliform germs, with 25% testing positive for E coli. Sinks, sponges, and dishcloths left damp become perfect breeding grounds for Salmonella and Listeria. Microbiologists insist that simple changes such as washing hands carefully, keeping raw and cooked foods separate, sanitizing surfaces, and avoiding rinsing raw meat can dramatically reduce risk.

One of the most surprising findings was about bar soap used for dishwashing. When left in wet soap holders with food residue, bar soaps become a bacterial swamp. Using the same bar soap to wash multiple items can cause cross-contamination, and leftover soap residues on plates and utensils pose further microbial and chemical risks.

On the other hand, liquid dishwashing solutions are sealed, completely hygienic, and easy to rinse off. They also work much better in rural areas, where hard water, rich in minerals like calcium and magnesium, makes cleaning more difficult.

The danger isn’t limited to dishes and sponges. Vegetables, fish, and meat from local wet markets often carry pesticide residues, heavy metals, and bacterial contamination. Without proper cleaning at home, these hazards end up directly on our plates, posing a long-term health risk.

Dr Latiful Bari, an eminent food microbiologist and safety researcher at the University of Dhaka, stated: “Presence of harmful Bacteria on vegetables in Bangladesh is a serious concern, yet most studies focus only on pesticides or chemicals. Our research shows harmful bacterial contamination in vegetables, kitchens, on sponges, and dishwashing utensils should equally be a matter of grave concern. The Regulatory Authority / NGO must raise awareness about kitchen bacterial contamination and cleanliness procedures to improve food safety."

So, is our kitchen making us sick? The evidence suggests it could be. The remedy, however, is simple and inexpensive: adopt smarter, safer habits. Replace sponges frequently, switch from bar soap to liquid dish soap, keep surfaces dry, clean refrigerators and utensils on a regular basis, and store food properly.

In a country where the kitchen is the heart of the home, it must also serve as the first line of defense for health. Kitchen hygiene is not a luxury; it’s a public health necessity. A few minor improvements today could protect many families from preventable diseases tomorrow.

Chowdhury Naim Ahmed Mujibis a consultant at an NGO in Bangladesh.

title: Ceramics in Bangladesh: A story of craft, commerce, and culture
body:
Long before becoming an industrial powerhouse, Bangladesh’s relationship with ceramics was rooted in tradition.

For centuries, local artisans shaped clay into terracotta pottery, roofing tiles, and decorative items—functional, humble, yet rich with cultural identity.

The journey from small-scale kumhars (potters) to a multi-million-dollar industry is a testament to Bangladesh’s evolving economic and creative landscape.

The modern ceramic industry took shape in the late 20th century, as urbanization and construction booms created demand for durable, aesthetically pleasing building materials.

Today, Bangladesh produces over 35 million square meters of tiles annually, supplying not only local markets but also exporting to more than 50 countries.

The sector employs over 50,000 people and contributes significantly to the national economy.

Walk into any contemporary Bangladeshi home, office, or commercial space, and you’ll notice a quiet revolution—one shaped by ceramics.

Flooring, wall claddings, kitchen backsplashes, and bathrooms have undergone a dramatic transformation, moving from purely functional surfaces to design statements.

Architects and interior designers now leverage ceramics to create visual continuity, texture, and identity.

Large-format tiles make compact apartments feel spacious; wood-effect porcelain planks bring warmth to urban settings; marble-look slabs offer luxury without the cost or maintenance.

In commercial spaces—from hospitals to hotels—ceramics combine hygiene, durability, and style.

At the forefront of this transformation is RAK Ceramics—the country’s only homegrown multinational tiles and sanitaryware brand.

With a footprint in over 150 countries, RAK has successfully infused international design standards and cutting-edge innovation into Bangladeshi homes, while simultaneously showcasing local craftsmanship on the global stage.

Among its standout offerings is the Rocker Series (80x80cm), engineered for high-traffic commercial and residential spaces.

These tiles combine slip resistance and durability with a sleek, modern finish, making them ideal for lobbies, malls, and offices.

The Elegant Slabs (60x120cm) redefine spatial aesthetics with their large-format design, creating seamless surfaces that suit open-plan living rooms, kitchens, and even exterior facades.

Their minimal grout lines contribute to a clean, sophisticated look.

Meanwhile, the Vista & Rocker Wall Tiles (30x60cm) offer a versatile range of finishes—from matte to glossy, textured to printed—making them a popular choice for feature walls, bathrooms, and kitchens.

These tiles not only elevate visual appeal but also ensure easy maintenance and bold, expressive interiors.

RAK has also redefined bathroom spaces with smart, sustainable sanitaryware solutions that balance hygiene and design.

The Touchless Sensation Water Closet introduces motion-sensor flushing technology, promoting cleanliness while minimizing water waste—an innovation tailored for modern, health-conscious households.

Complementing this is the Cloud Wall-Hung Water Closet, a sleek, space-saving fixture that aligns with minimalist design trends.

Its elevated form not only enhances visual elegance but also simplifies cleaning, offering both style and practicality in contemporary bathroom design.

The adoption of ceramics reflects broader shifts in Bangladeshi lifestyle—aspirational, practical, and increasingly global.

Urban families now prioritize materials that are easy to maintain, resistant to humidity and flooding, and adaptable to both contemporary and traditional aesthetics.

As environmental consciousness grows, the industry is pivoting toward sustainable production.

Energy-efficient kilns, recycled materials, and water-saving technologies are becoming standard.

RAK Ceramics, for instance, has incorporated green manufacturing practices and offers products compliant with global sustainability benchmarks.

With trends like biophilic design, maximalist patterns, and digital printing gaining traction, ceramics will continue to enable creative expression—whether through jungle-themed bathroom tiles or terrazzo-inspired flooring.

Bangladesh’s ceramic industry is no longer just about utility—it’s about identity, innovation, and integration into global design narratives.

Brands like RAK Ceramics have played a pivotal role in this evolution, offering products that marry form and function while empowering architects, designers, and homeowners to reimagine their spaces.

From the ancestral kilns of potters to the digital showrooms of today, ceramics remain a medium of both tradition and transformation—proving that some of the best foundations for the future are built, quite literally, from the ground up.

title: The blooming online world of perfumes in Bangladesh
body:
Fragrance collecting is on the rise worldwide and Bangladesh is no exception – a community driven by passion, nostalgia and an unrelenting curiosity for the magic of scent.

For some, a bottle of perfume is simply a daily indulgence, a spritz of confidence before heading out the door.

But for perfume collectors, it’s so much more. It’s an art form, a time capsule and a deep, often personal expression of identity.

Finding the right fragrance. Photo: Collected

Bangladesh’s expanding online perfume circle is bringing together fragrance lovers like never before.

Fragrance collecting in Bangladesh is thriving through vibrant online communities like Fragcomm Bangladesh, Perfume & Attar Group of Bangladesh and Fat Friends Fragrance, etc.

Across Facebook groups, Instagram pages and local forums, enthusiasts come together to share reviews, swap or sell rare bottles, discuss their SOTDs (scents of the day) and uncover hidden gems – turning a personal passion into a collective experience.

What was once a niche has become a vibrant online space where people connect over scents and memories.

“The thrill is in the chase”, says Maimuna Ameen, a Dhaka-based collector who has been building her collection for over a year.

Shihab Ahmed, describing the excitement of perfume collecting, said: “Finding an old formulation of Shalimar or a discontinued Jo Malone scent feels like striking gold.”

Perfume collecting is not a cheap hobby. Bottled scents can range from Tk5,000 to over Tk1 lakh, depending on the brand, rarity and age.

Some collectors even invest in fragrances the way others invest in fine art or wine.

Vintage collecting feels like treasure hunting.

Finding the right fragrance. Photo: Collected

There’s a growing resale market for high-end or discontinued scents, and popular perfumes often increase in value over time.

But for most collectors, the price is justified by the joy.

“Each bottle is a little world I get to visit,” says Tasnuva Azad, another collector.

Also, if you have unused or partially used perfumes, communities are ideal for buying, selling or trading.

They help you refresh your collection while finding new favorites as budget alternatives.

Always verify authenticity and condition before making a deal for a smooth experience.

Instagram, Reddit forums and YouTube reviewers have transformed perfume collecting from a solitary activity into a lively global conversation.

Online fragrance reviewers, often called “fragheads,” have cult-like followings.

Collectors share “shelfies” (photos of their collections), unbox new finds, review scents and even swap rare samples.

Their detailed breakdowns and storytelling abilities often influence a collector’s decision as much as the scent itself.

What draws someone into perfume collecting?

For many, it starts with a memory – a scent worn by a loved one long ago.

Scent is one of the strongest triggers of memory, and collectors often describe their shelves as libraries of emotion – each bottle holding stories, places and people.

Finding the right fragrance. Photo: Collected

But collecting isn’t just about memory.

It’s the skill and creativity behind making perfume that excites them.

And then there’s the packaging, beautiful bottles, crystal caps and heritage designs – that often make a perfume look like a piece of art to display.

Sometimes the rarity of limited-edition releases creates an addictive mix of art and alchemy.

Perfume collecting is evolving, now driven by sustainability, personalization and emotion.

From refillable bottles to custom scents, it’s no longer just about owning fragrances, but curating memories and identity, one note at a time.

title: Pick the perfect SOTD – scent of the day
body:
Finding the right fragrance is more than just picking a pretty bottle.

Whether it’s a long-lasting perfume, a light body mist or a quick-fix body spray, your choice of scent says something about you before you even speak.

But with endless options lining the shelves, how do you choose the one that truly fits you?

Before you start testing, it’s important to understand what sets perfumes, mists and body sprays apart.

Perfume (eau de parfum/parfum) is a high concentration of fragrance oils, rich, long-lasting and usually applied on pulse points.

Body mist is a lighter version of fragrance with more water and alcohol – refreshing and subtle, perfect for layering or casual wear.

Body sprays are typically more affordable. These are often stronger than mists at first but fade faster.

Understanding fragrance notes is very important while choosing the scent.

Every fragrance has three layers.

Top notes: The initial burst you smell when you first spray.

Middle notes (heart): They develop after a few minutes. These are the soul of the fragrance—often fruity, floral or spicy.

Base notes: The scent that lingers. Think woods, musks or vanilla-warm and deep.

Finding the right fragrance. Photo: Collected

Longevity is about how long the fragrance lasts on your skin.

Sillage tells about how far your scent travels, like does it stay close or leave a trail?

Parfum (extrait de parfum) has the highest fragrance oil concentration at 20–30%, lasting 8 to 12 hours or more.

Eau de parfum (EDP) has 15–20% and stays for 6 to 8 hours, making it a popular daily choice.

Eau de toilette (EDT) is lighter at 5–15%, lasting 3 to 5 hours. It is great for daytime.

Eau de cologne (EDC), with 2–5%, lasts 2 to 3 hours and is often fresh and citrusy.

The lightest is eau fraîche with just 1–3%, lasting 1 to 2 hours, perfect for a quick refresh.

Perfumes have the highest longevity, but many mists and body sprays can last longer if layered correctly.

Try pairing a matching lotion or oil underneath.

Fragrances are often grouped into families based on their scent profile. Recognizing which you naturally gravitate toward can narrow down your options.

Floral scents are romantic and feminine, featuring notes like rose, jasmine or peony.

Fresh or citrus fragrances feel clean and energizing, with hints of lemon, bergamot or green tea.

Woody perfumes are warm and earthy, built around cedar, sandalwood or patchouli.

Oriental scents are rich and spicy, blending amber, vanilla or cinnamon.

Lastly, gourmand fragrances evoke sweetness and comfort with edible notes like caramel, coffee or chocolate.

Pay attention to what you’re drawn to when smelling others or testing on yourself.

Perfume oils are alcohol-free and contain a high percentage of pure fragrance, usually between 20–40%.

They tend to last longer on the skin and offer a softer, more personal scent experience.

Because they don’t evaporate quickly, the fragrance unfolds slowly and stays close to the skin, making them ideal for all-day wear.

Finding the right fragrance. Photo: Collected

Perfumes react differently depending on your body chemistry. What smells amazing on someone else may not work the same way on you.

Always spray on your wrist or inner elbow and wait 15–20 minutes before making a decision.

Avoid testing more than three scents at once, as your nose will get overwhelmed.

To choose wisely, don’t rely on the first whiff.

Let the fragrance settle and see how it evolves on your skin.

Each scent has its place in your routine.

Perfumes for special occasions or lasting impact, mists for day-to-day freshness and sprays for gym bags or on-the-go.

For humid climates or hot days, lighter mists or sprays work better. In winter, stronger perfumes tend to last longer and feel comforting.

In the end, the perfect scent is one that makes you feel like yourself or a version of you that you love.

Trendy perfumes come and go, but the right scent is the one that truly reflects your personality.

Whether it’s a luxurious designer perfume or a budget-friendly body spray, it should lift your mood, spark a memory or boost your confidence.

So take your time, explore and let your nose lead the way.

title: Who said mehedi isn’t for Eid-ul-Azha?
body:
Eid-ul-Azha, the “Festival of Sacrifice” is often seen as a more practical and solemn occasion compared to the colorful flair of Eid-ul-Fitr.

With the focus on Qurbani, early morning preparations and hosting guests, many girls and young women have gradually moved away from the  ritual of applying mehedi on this Eid. The reasons vary: time constraints, the messiness of the application or simply the belief that it’s more of a “fitr” thing.

But does that mean Eid-ul-Azha doesn’t deserve the joy of deep red palms and floral fingertips? Absolutely not.

Mehedi has never just been about decoration, it’s an emotion. An Eid eve tradition that carries memories of laughter, cousins gathering on the floor, cones being passed around and sleepy eyes waiting for the stain to set.

It’s one of the purest and most personal forms of celebration.

Skipping mehedi on Eid-ul-Azha may feel like a practical choice, but in doing so, we slowly erase a piece of the festive charm.

This Eid, why not bring it back? Even if the day begins with early morning kitchen duty and ends with hosting guests, a little mehedi the night before can shift the mood for you and for those around you.

It’s a reminder that joy has a place in every kind of celebration, not just the glamorous ones.

Let your fingers bloom this Eid-ul-Azha.

You’re allowed to look and feel beautiful, even while carrying out responsibilities.

Because Eid is not just about what we do for others. It’s also about what we do for ourselves.

And sometimes, all it takes is the smell of fresh mehedi to feel the Eid magic again.

title: Eid-ul-Fitr: A festival of harmony and joy
body:
After a month of fasting, Eid brings with it a message of contentment and celebration, along with the call for unity, harmony, and joy. People return home to be with their loved ones. Like every year, at least 25 million people will have traveled to different parts of the country on the occasion of Eid.

Eid ul Fitr is an Arabic word, meaning happiness or festivity, which originates from the Arabic word “Aud” and Fitr, translating to the breaking or conclusion of fasting.

Eid-ul-Fitr means the festival of fast-breaking, which will return after a year.

Eid-ul-Fitr is celebrated on the first day of Shawaal, the tenth month in the Muslim calendar, to mark the end of a month-long fast during the month of Ramadan.

According to a Hadith attributed to Anas ibn Malik, a companion of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), the two festivals of Eid ul-Fitr and Eid ul-Azha were instituted by the Prophet after his journey from Mecca to Medina.

The importance of Eid-ul-Fitr is purely spiritual. It is the day when Muslims thank Allah for giving them the will, the strength, and the endurance to fast and obey his commandment during the holy month of Ramadan.

Eid is supposed to purify us physically, mentally, and spiritually while we look inside ourselves and reflect and give back to the community. It is also meant to eliminate the feeling of hatred among us.

Only if this happens will our celebration of Eid be considered successful.

Historically, it has been seen that despite the crowds in trains and buses and the disruption of schedules, the unquenchable joy of the people has not faded. Everyone is filled with joy and happiness in celebrating Eid.

Eid is undoubtedly the biggest religious festival in Bangladesh. It creates an atmosphere of unity and harmony in all walks of life through the exchange of joy and greetings between individuals. Rich, poor, high, and low, everyone participates in the joy and festivities of Eid with their families and relatives as much as they can.

Just as we practice self-restraint in the teachings of fasting in Ramadan, we must also practice social responsibility during Eid. The flow of greetings, harmony, and cordiality that is present in the atmosphere during Eid festival increases the joy of the individual many times over, and a portion of personal joy is transformed into the vastness of social joy.

In Bangladesh, a lot of harshness, selfishness, and bad behavior has been developing over the years. Instead of human values, brutality is also seen in personal and professional life. Instead of thinking about the welfare of people, some people are engaging in bribery, corruption, adulteration, and price gouging. Some people are displaying brutality like murder, rape, and violence against women and children.

One must consider the real message of Ramadan and Eid. It carries the message of friendship, harmony, and joy at the end of Ramadan, giving us an opportunity for self-realization. It encourages us to understand social responsibility as human beings.

As a result, instead of excessive excess of personal joy and enjoyment during the Eid festival, it is everyone's duty in the existing context to be as humane and considerate as possible. It is everyone's duty to understand the suffering of the oppressed, distressed, and neglected people in society. Because festivals and joy are meaningful and successful only when they can bring smiles to everyone's faces.

Greatness lies in being able to be happy and joyful with everyone. Nothing can be greater than eradicating the fear, panic, and despair among all and spreading the unbridled fruits of harmony and joy.

On the occasion of Eid celebrations, a large number of people from the capital and other big cities go to their villages. May their Eid journey be smooth and comfortable.

It is our duty to ensure that everyone can enjoy the joy of Eid equally. May the world be free from all forms of violence, hatred, and strife.

May the horrors of religious extremism and terrorism be eradicated. May the bonds of inter-religious harmony and brotherhood be strengthened. May the coming days be beautiful and adorned with beauty. May every soul be filled with laughter, happiness, and the joy of Eid. May an atmosphere of moderation, brotherhood, and harmony prevail in individual, family, society, and national life—this is the sincere wish of the Eid festival.

title: Lost tradition of Eid cards: A nostalgic journey
body:
Once upon a time, the joyous arrival of Eid was incomplete without the charm of Eid cards.

These delicate pieces of paper carried more than just festive greetings; they were tiny messengers of love, nostalgia and heartfelt connections. Wrapped in colorful envelopes and adorned with shimmering calligraphy, Eid cards were once the tangible embodiment of warmth in an era where emotions traveled by hand, not by pixels.

There was something magical about selecting the perfect Eid card. Stationery shops in Bangladesh, particularly in places like Nilkhet, New Market, Eraki Maath and various roadside stalls, fields, would gleam with an array of beautifully crafted cards, each adorned with intricate patterns, crescent moons and golden embellishments. Some cards had featured photos of our favorite cartoon characters, Barbie princesses, heroes, heroines and popular figures from sports, among others. Prices varied based on design and quality—simpler cards were available for as low as Tk5 to 10, while premium ones with embossing, glitter and pop-up elements could cost up to Tk50 or more.

The excitement of flipping through them, feeling their texture and choosing one that best expressed emotions was a cherished ritual. Some bore poetic verses, while others held simple yet profound words—each a reflection of the sender’s affection.

Sometimes, we even took the time to craft Eid cards ourselves. With colorful paper, sketch pens and a sprinkle of creativity, we poured our hearts into handmade cards. A carefully drawn crescent moon, a heartfelt message in our own handwriting and a personal touch made these creations even more special. The joy of making and receiving a handmade card was unparalleled, reflecting the effort and sincerity of the giver.

But with the dawn of the digital era, Eid cards faded into the background, replaced by instant messages and virtual greetings. Eid cards started to vanish in the early 2000s, as mobile phones and the internet became more accessible. The touch of embossed paper, the scent of fresh ink and the anticipation of tearing open an envelope have been lost to the swiftness of screens. Today, people mostly send Eid Mubarak messages via WhatsApp, Facebook and other digital platforms, making the once-essential Eid card a rare relic of the past. When a card arrived, it was treasured like a keepsake, slipped between book pages or tucked into memory boxes to be revisited in quiet moments of reminiscence. For those who cherished this tradition, some still keep old Eid cards stored as tokens of memory, preserving the emotions attached to handwritten wishes and intricate designs.

Unlike fleeting digital messages, Eid cards held permanence. The journey of these cards was one of patience and anticipation, as they traveled across cities, sometimes even borders, to reach the hands of loved ones. The joy of receiving a card was unparalleled, its weight in hand symbolizing the sender’s effort and sincerity, making distances feel shorter and hearts grow fonder. Handing it over to our loved ones was also a delightful experience.

Yet, for those who remember, the memory of Eid cards lingers like an old melody, a reminder of a time when emotions were penned down with love, not typed in haste. Perhaps, in reviving this lost tradition, we can rediscover the joy of heartfelt expressions—where wishes are not merely sent but felt, where greetings are not just received but held close, just like in the golden days of Eid cards.

title: Essence of salami: A heartwarming Eid celebration
body:
Eid-ul-Fitr and Eid-ul-Azha hold a special place in the hearts of Muslims worldwide. These joyous occasions mark moments of unity, gratitude, and celebration with loved ones.

From attending the early morning Eid prayers to relishing grand feasts, the festive spirit is evident in every home.

Among the various cherished customs of Eid, one tradition stands out across generations—giving and receiving salami.

As a child, one of the most exciting moments for me was waking up early on Eid, getting dressed in new clothes, and rushing to my dadi (grandmother) to receive salami from her.

This was always the first stop before eagerly collecting salami from my parents and relatives. My cousins and I followed this ritual religiously on every Eid, cherishing the joy it brought us.

Even now, as an adult, I still eagerly await salami—not for the money itself, but for the love and blessings it represents.

Cultural significance of salami

The tradition of salami has deep cultural roots in Muslim communities.

The act of giving salami is more than just a monetary exchange; it serves as a token of appreciation and a thoughtful gift.

It is a symbol of warmth from elders, and a beautiful reminder of the joy that has been passed down through generations

Historically, salami has been a way to teach children the concept of generosity.

Just as they receive during childhood, they later grow up to give, continuing the cycle of kindness.

Shift from receiving to giving

Receiving salami on Eid is a timeless tradition, deeply woven into the celebration. Children eagerly await their father’s return from the mosque after the Eid prayer, bowing down and touching his feet as a sign of respect before receiving their salami.

Though this practice has faded in some families over the years, it has not disappeared entirely.

While some continue to uphold the tradition, others have adapted it to modern expressions of respect.

As I grew up collecting salami and stepped into adulthood, the time came for me to take on a new role—the transition from receiving to giving salami.

There is a unique joy in handing over salami and witnessing the excitement on the faces of younger family members.

Spirit of generosity and unity

Beyond salami, Eid is synonymous with acts of giving. Charity, or zakat, is a fundamental part of Eid-ul-Fitr, ensuring that the less fortunate can also partake in the celebrations.

Families prepare lavish meals and invite neighbors and friends, strengthening the bonds of community.

Eid-ul-Azha, on the other hand, emphasizes sacrifice and sharing, where meat from the sacrificed animal is distributed among the poor, relatives, and friends.

These acts of generosity highlight the core values of Eid—kindness, sharing, and gratitude.

Preserving the tradition

As times change, traditions evolve, but the essence of salami remains a beloved part of Eid.

Whether given in cash, through a bank transfer, or as a thoughtful gift, it is a gesture of love that transcends generations.

What makes salami special is the emotions tied to it—the anticipation, the exchange of blessings, and the continuity of a heartwarming practice.

Whether you are a child eagerly waiting for salami or an adult happily passing it on, the tradition brings a unique joy that makes Eid even more memorable.

title: The evolution of Eid cards
body:
Even 10 to 15 years ago, the joy of Eid meant new clothes and handmade Eid cards. Digital messaging cannot compare to the feeling of writing greetings on your own handmade Eid cards and telling your friends "Eid Mubarak". In the current era of social media, the traditional custom of distributing Eid cards has been lost.

I remember that I used to start making Eid cards three to four days before Eid. Sometimes I would use watercolors, crayons, or cut out glossy paper to make these Eid cards. I would try to make cards that were more beautiful than my friends'.

On the morning of Eid, these cards were exchanged among friends. Which doubled the joy of Eid.

After a few years, these Eid cards started being sold in various shops. These shops were available in cities, neighborhoods, and even villages. Many boys and girls would make Eid cards themselves and set up shops to sell them. After staying up all night to make Eid cards and selling them in the afternoon to get the money, the joy of Eid seemed to double.

Then came the Eid cards printed in the press. These Eid cards would have "Eid Mubarak" written in large letters with greetings. There would also be natural scenes, birds, mosque domes, pictures of Makkah Sharif, etc. On the cards, there would be a commemorative moon and star on the domed mosque. Or "Eid Mubarak" written in the middle of a bouquet of red roses.

With Eid in sight, there was a booming business in cities and villages everywhere.

After that, the popularity of handmade Eid cards gradually stopped. Now, school and college boys and girls no longer come in groups to buy Eid cards for friends and relatives like before.

However, although the trend of exchanging Eid cards at the individual level has decreased, the popularity of group-based Eid cards has increased. Starting from government and private institutions, various organizations are now using Eid cards to express their wishes.

Then, the touch of technology came to Eid greetings. SMS and MMS took over the place of Eid cards. We used to try to write greetings as beautifully as possible. I would type these greetings on my button mobile phone. Then I would send them one by one to my friends' mobile numbers. Different greetings would also come from my friends' numbers. The joy that came from taking the time to think about writing SMS greetings is now not available in anything else.

This tendency to write SMS with difficulty also decreased to a large extent later. Smartphones and social media came along. Most people now fulfill their obligations by sending greetings on Facebook, Messenger, email, e-cards, X (formerly Twitter), TikTok and WhatsApp. These social media are being used as an alternative means of greetings instead of cards made with difficulty by hand.

Currently, more than a hundred online card-making websites have been developed for Eid cards. When you go to these websites, you can see thousands of Eid card samples.

You can choose the card of your choice from these samples and add your own design to it to create an Eid card. There are also separate websites for sending status or greeting messages on social media. You can easily copy the message of your choice from these websites and send it to your friends.

Shopkeepers said that earlier, Eid cards could not be sold from the beginning of Ramadan. Each shop sold one to five lakh taka of Eid cards every day. Everyone used to wait for this time. Now, a handful of organizations order a small number of cards. Apart from them, cards are not printed for retail sale.

title: Unspoken significance of the Tupi
body:
During the last Eid-ul-Fitr, my father handed me a crisp white tupi just before we left for the Eid prayer. "Wear this," he said, his tone neither forceful nor casual. It was the same way his father must have handed him one, decades ago.

Growing up, the tupi never felt like a necessity to me. I saw it as an accessory, something optional, something that didn't quite fit into my idea of personal style. My elders wore it with an effortless grace, as though it was a part of them, but I struggled to understand why it held such importance.

Yet, on that particular morning, standing before my father, watching him smooth out the creases in his own tupi, I saw something I hadn't noticed before—a quiet reverence, a silent ritual of continuity.

The tupi or a prayer cap—is an understated yet significant part of Eid attire for many Muslim men. For some, it completes their panjabi, a final touch to the ensemble worn for prayers. For others, it holds deeper meaning—cultural, religious, and familial.

It is a symbol of modesty, an unspoken declaration of faith, and in many ways, a bridge between generations.

In the days leading up to Eid, the markets are alive with vendors calling out to customers, their stalls stacked with tupis of every variety—embroidered, crocheted, plain, colorful, imported, locally made.

In Bangladesh, the classic white cotton tupi remains the most popular, a staple in many households. Yet, others opt for ornate designs, intricate patterns.

But beyond the bustling commerce of these markets lies a quieter, more personal tale.

I remember seeing my grandfather’s tupi as a child, a soft, worn-out piece of cloth that had lost its original shape. It had been washed so many times that its white had turned an almost ivory shade. But to him, it was never something to replace. It held memories of countless prayers, of Eid mornings spent side by side with loved ones who were no longer here.

When I think about it now, I realize that for him, that tupi was not just a tradition—it was a reminder. A piece of the past, held close.

Yet, not everyone wears a tupi with ease. As a child, I often felt it was an imposition, something insisted upon by elders, something I wore out of respect rather than conviction. I would see young boys at the Eid prayer, their tupis slightly oversized, constantly adjusting them, as if trying to find comfort in something they had yet to fully understand. Perhaps they, like me, would grow into it—not just in size, but in meaning.

Coming back to the morning of last Eid-ul-Fitr, as I stood in the vast expanse of the Eid prayer, surrounded by hundreds of men—some with pristine white caps, others with worn and fraying ones—I understood something: the tupi is not about uniformity, nor is it merely about religious conformity. It is a symbol of standing shoulder to shoulder with a community that stretches across generations.

A man to my left adjusted his son’s tupi, making sure it sat properly on his head. The boy, no older than five or six, fidgeted impatiently, not yet aware of the significance of this moment. And yet, years from now, perhaps he too will recall this morning—the touch of his father’s hands fixing his cap, the sea of white before him, the collective murmur of takbirs filling the air.

Tradition has a way of finding us, even when we do not seek it. Some embrace it willingly; others take time to understand its weight. But certain things—like a tupi passed from father to son—carry stories too precious to be left behind.

This Eid, as I once again pick up my tupi, I do so not out of obligation, but out of understanding.

title: Are we losing the joy of hiding Eid clothes?
body:
Eid means joy, Eid means happiness. One of the components of this happiness is new clothes. Rich, poor, and middle-class people try to wear new clothes as much as possible on the day of Eid-ul-Fitr. And in any family, children have priority when it comes to new clothes. All parents try to give their children the clothes they like the most.

On the day of Eid, the turn of wearing new clothes begins with going to prayer in the morning. Then, walking around in new clothes all day. However, with the development of technology, there has been a change in the way people hide or go overboard with Eid clothes.

There was a time when people tried to hide new clothes before Eid. The custom was that if someone outside the house sees the clothes before Eid, then they will become old. That is, people will see the Eid clothes on the day of Eid.

Although children were ahead in this competition of hiding Eid clothes, adults were not far behind. Even among adults, there was a tendency to hide new clothes from friends and relatives until Eid. It was not uncommon for children to burst into tears if someone saw the new clothes before Eid!

It is quite difficult for others to experience or express this “secret joy” except for those who have had the experience of hiding these clothes.

However, over time, our lifestyles have changed. This has also affected Eid clothes. It can be said that a kind of “show-off” competition has started. This show-off tendency is especially seen on social media. Who bought how many expensive shoes, clothes, jewelry? What is whose Eid budget, who bought how many clothes? We have a negative obsession with seeking self-satisfaction through publicity.

If anyone has the ability, they can spend more, buy more clothes. There is nothing wrong with that. But I call this “negative” in the sense that; your friends, colleagues or relatives may not have the ability that you have. This “show-off” of yours may be causing her emotional pain without her knowing it. Maybe her child is making a demand on you; which she cannot afford to meet. As a result, it is becoming painful for her and her family.

However, that does not mean that you should not show your ability to people. But at the same time, you should also remember that it should not go to the extreme. Your joy should not be the cause of other people's secret pain. May Eid joy be distributed evenly; Eid Mubarak.

(This article has been translated from Bangla)

title: Eid shopping: Online or in-store—which one wins?
body:
As Eid draws closer, the excitement of shopping takes over. Almost half of this blessed month has passed, and the festive rush is in full swing.

But the big question arises—should you shop online for convenience or step into the bustling markets for a hands-on experience?

Each option comes with its own perks and pitfalls. While one offers ease, the other promises authenticity.

So, which should you choose?

Online shopping is ideal for those who prefer avoiding crowded markets and shopping from the comfort of home, all variety in one place.

No long queues, no exhausting walks—just a few clicks and your Eid outfit is on its way.

You can’t feel the fabric, assess the embroidery or try on the fit before purchasing.

Plus, deliveries take 3–4 days, sometimes longer.

“I once ordered a gorgeous embroidered dress online, only to receive something that looked nothing like the picture. It was a disaster,” shared Mitu Akhter, a university student in a page review section.

If you crave the true essence of Eid shopping, visiting stores is the way to go.

You can see, touch and try on your outfit before making a purchase.

The festive ambiance, the aroma of street food, and the sight of dazzling displays add to the experience of in-store shopping.

However, with the last days of Ramadan, markets become unbearably packed, making shopping a test of patience.

“I love the thrill of finding the perfect dress after hours of searching. It’s exhausting but worth it,” said Ayesha Khatun, a frequent Eid shopper.

Online shopping offers a limitless selection of styles, colors and brands at your fingertips -- no need to hop from one shop to another.

However, digital perfection can be deceiving—what you see is not always what you get.

In-store shopping offers limited choices but comes with its own advantages.

Unlike online shopping, you can bargain with sellers, customize orders and walk out with your purchase in hand.

“Online shopping is tempting, but finding the right size is always a gamble,” said Tania, who prefers in-store purchases.

Online shopping has perks like flash sales, discount codes and bundle deals which make it seem cost-effective.

But beware—hidden shipping charges can be surprisingly high, sometimes almost half the cost of the outfit or thing.

While local markets give you room to haggle, often leading to better deals than what’s advertised online.

Plus, there are no unexpected delivery charges.

“If you know how to bargain, in-store shopping is always a win-win,” said Tasniya Farha, who swears by market shopping.

But there is a travel cost that you have to keep in mind.

Also some fixed-price shops tend to be overpriced, offering no room for bargaining.

Online shopping can be a gamble. Some stores have strict return policies, while others refuse to accept returns at all. Prepayment policies also add risk, as not all sellers are reliable.

In-store shopping lets you swap sizes or designs instantly if something doesn’t fit: no waiting, no hassle.

“I once paid in full for an online order and the page disappeared the next day. Never again!” complained Rafi Bin Asad, recalling a bad experience.

If convenience and variety top your list, online shopping is the way to go.

But if you prioritize quality and fit, hitting the stores is the smarter choice. Want the best of both worlds?

Browse designs online first, then visit stores to finalize your pick.

title: How to choose the right AC capacity: A comprehensive guide for Bangladeshi homes
body:
When it comes to buying anACin Bangladesh, one of the most critical decisions you’ll make is selecting the right capacity. An undersized AC will struggle to cool your space, while an oversized unit can lead to unnecessary energy consumption and higher electricity bills. In Bangladesh’s sweltering summers, choosing the correct AC capacity ensures optimal comfort, efficiency, and cost savings. Here’s a step-by-step guide to help you make the best choice.

The cooling capacity of an air conditioner is measured in British Thermal Units (BTU). Simply put, BTU indicates how much heat the AC can remove from a room in one hour. The higher the BTU, the more powerful the AC. For instance, an AC with 5,000 BTU is suitable for small spaces like compact bedrooms, while a unit with 12,000 BTU or more is ideal for larger rooms or open-plan areas.

In Bangladesh’s intense heatwaves, understanding BTU is essential. An undersized AC will run continuously without effectively cooling, while an oversized unit will cool too quickly, leaving the room humid and uncomfortable. To avoid these issues, it’s crucial to calculate the exact BTU requirement for your space. To help you with that, theStar Tech AC Ton Calculatorwill come in handy. This user-friendly application considers factors like room size, insulation, and environmental conditions to recommend the ideal AC capacity.

The first step in choosing the right AC capacity is measuring the area of the room you want to cool. Start by calculating the square footage of the space by multiplying its length and width. Once you have this figure, you can estimate the required BTU based on general guidelines. For example, a small bedroom measuring 10 feet by 15 feet (150 square feet) typically requires an AC with 5,000–6,000 BTU. A slightly larger bedroom or study room, around 200–250 square feet, would need an AC with 7,000–8,000 BTU, while living rooms or combined spaces spanning 350–550 square feet may require units with 12,000–14,000 BTU or higher.

However, these figures are just starting points. Several factors can influence the required BTU. For instance, high ceilings can trap more heat, necessitating a higher-capacity AC. Similarly, poorly insulated walls or large windows can increase the cooling load, requiring additional BTU. Open-plan spaces, such as combined living and dining areas, often demand a more powerful AC to ensure even cooling throughout. By carefully assessing your room size and layout, you can narrow down the range of AC capacities that will work best for your needs.

The purpose of the room affects the required AC capacity. Bedrooms, typically smaller and occupied by one or two people, need lower-capacity units. Living rooms, which host more people, require higher BTU. Kitchens, with added heat from appliances, also need slightly higher-capacity ACs.

Additionally, consider how often the room is used. Spaces occupied throughout the day, like home offices, need ACs that can handle continuous operation. Less frequently used rooms, like guest bedrooms, can work with lower-capacity units.

Bangladesh’s climate, marked by high humidity and soaring temperatures, can significantly affect an AC’s performance. Rooms with large windows or west-facing walls absorb more heat from direct sunlight, requiring a higher BTU AC to counteract the warmth. Similarly, poor ventilation or inadequate insulation can trap heat, increasing the cooling load.

High humidity adds another layer of complexity. While most ACs also function as dehumidifiers, models with advanced dehumidification features are ideal for areas with extreme humidity. These not only cool the space but also improve indoor air quality, benefiting households with allergies or respiratory concerns.

On the other hand, well-insulated rooms or spaces shaded by trees may allow for a slightly lower-capacity AC. By considering these environmental factors, you can ensure your AC operates efficiently without overworking itself.

While selecting the right capacity is crucial, energy efficiency should also be a top priority. Look for inverter ACs, which adjust their cooling output based on the room’s temperature. Unlike traditional ACs, which operate at full capacity until the desired temperature is reached and then shut off, inverter models maintain a consistent temperature by modulating their power usage. This not only reduces electricity consumption but also extends the lifespan of the unit.

Energy efficiency is often indicated by the Energy Efficiency Ratio (EER) or star rating of the AC. A higher EER or more stars signify better efficiency, meaning the AC consumes less electricity for the same amount of cooling. While these models may have a higher upfront cost, they save money on electricity bills over time, making them a cost-effective choice in the long run. Retailers like Star Tech Ltd. offer a wide range of energy-efficient ACs, including inverter models from brands like LG, Samsung, and Gree.

Choosing the wrong AC capacity can lead to a host of problems, both in terms of performance and cost. One common mistake is oversizing the AC. While it might seem logical to opt for a more powerful unit, an oversized AC will cool the room quickly but shut off before adequately removing humidity. This leaves the space feeling damp and uncomfortable, negating the purpose of the AC. Additionally, frequent cycling increases wear and tear, shortening the unit’s lifespan.

Undersizing the AC is equally problematic. A unit with insufficient BTU will struggle to cool the room, running continuously and consuming excessive electricity. This not only leads to skyrocketing energy bills but also causes the AC to overheat and break down more frequently.

Another pitfall is ignoring future needs. For example, if you plan to use the room for different purposes—such as converting a study into a guest bedroom—you should factor in potential changes when selecting the AC capacity. Planning ahead ensures your investment remains relevant and effective over time.

If you’re unsure about calculating BTU or selecting the right AC, don’t hesitate to seek professional advice. Many retailers, includingStar Tech Ltd., offer free consultations to help customers choose the best AC for their needs. Star Tech AC Ton Calculator also plays a vital role in selecting the right air conditioner for your room. Their experts can assess your space, take into account factors like room size, usage patterns, and environmental conditions, and recommend the ideal capacity and model.

Based on typical room sizes in urban areas like Dhaka, Chittagong, and Sylhet, there are some popular AC capacities. Small bedrooms, which are common in apartments and compact homes, typically measure 100–150 square feet and require an AC with 1.0 Ton (12,000 BTU). Medium-sized bedrooms or study rooms, ranging from 150–250 square feet, usually need a 1.5 Ton (18,000 BTU) unit. Larger living rooms or combined spaces, spanning 300–500 square feet, often call for a 2.0 Ton (24,000 BTU) AC to ensure even and efficient cooling. These capacities align with the needs of most households, but always tailor your choice to your specific requirements.

Choosing the right AC capacity is a balancing act between room size, usage patterns, environmental factors, and energy efficiency. By understanding BTU requirements and avoiding common mistakes, you can ensure your AC delivers optimal cooling without breaking the bank.

As Bangladesh braces for another hot summer, investing in the right AC capacity will not only keep you comfortable but also save you money in the long run. So, take the time to assess your needs and beat the heat with confidence!

title: The evolution of graffiti: From ancient expressions to modern protest art
body:
Graffiti, often dismissed as mere vandalism, has a rich history that mirrors humanity's enduring desire for expression and identity.

From ancient cave paintings to contemporary protest art, graffiti has evolved into a powerful medium for social commentary and change.

The roots of graffiti can be traced back to prehistoric times, with cave paintings serving as early examples of human expression.

These depictions of daily life and rituals were humanity's initial attempts at visual communication.

In ancient Rome and Greece, graffiti took the form of inscriptions on public buildings and monuments, often conveying political messages or personal thoughts, highlighting its longstanding role in societal discourse.

The graffiti movement as we know it began in the late 1960s and early 1970s in urban centers like Philadelphia and New York City.

Artists such as Cornbread in Philadelphia and TAKI 183 in New York popularized tagging, turning cityscapes into canvases for personal expression.

This era marked the transformation of graffiti into a competitive and visible art form, with artists striving for recognition in bustling urban environments.

During the 1970s and 1980s, graffiti became intertwined with the burgeoning hip-hop culture, alongside rap, DJing, and breakdancing.

It served as a voice for marginalized youth, reflecting their struggles and aspirations.

Artists developed intricate styles, such as "wildstyle," characterized by complex, interlocking letters and vibrant colors, further cementing graffiti's place in urban culture.

As hip-hop culture gained international prominence, graffiti spread to cities worldwide, each incorporating unique cultural elements.

Over time, it transitioned from back alleys to art galleries, gaining recognition as a legitimate art form.

Artists like Banksy emerged as global icons, using graffiti to challenge societal norms and provoke thought, blurring the lines between street art and mainstream art.

In August 2024, Bangladesh experienced significant political upheaval, with graffiti playing a key role in the protests. The student-led movement, which began with calls for civil service recruitment reforms, grew into a larger campaign against government policies and corruption.

Graffiti became a powerful tool for protesters to express their dissatisfaction and unite the public.

Walls throughout Dhaka, particularly around Dhaka University, were adorned with colorful murals and slogans advocating for change.

These artworks not only expressed the youth's frustrations, but also rallied public support for the movement.

Graffiti's widespread use during this time period demonstrated its effectiveness as a means of political expression and mobilization.

Today, graffiti exists in a complex space between vandalism and art.

While some view it as defacement, others recognize its artistic value and its role in giving voice to marginalized communities.

The events in Bangladesh underscore graffiti's potential as a catalyst for social change, demonstrating its power to convey collective sentiments and inspire action.

From ancient cave walls to modern urban landscapes, graffiti has served as a medium for human expression, reflecting societal values, challenges, and transformations.

Its evolution into a tool for protest, as seen in the August 2024 movement in Bangladesh, underscores its enduring relevance and impact.

Graffiti stands as a testament to the transformative power of art in shaping societal narratives and driving change.

title: Starting the year right: Crafting meaningful new year’s resolutions
body:
As the calendar flips to January, many of us find ourselves reflecting on the year that has passed and setting intentions for the one ahead.

The idea of New Year’s resolutions is not new, but it remains a popular tradition.

Resolutions give us a chance to start fresh and focus on areas of life that we want to improve.

But how can we set goals that truly make a difference?

The process is easier than it seems, and anyone can do it with the right mindset.

New Year’s resolution ideas across different aspects of life.

Here are some simple yet effective tips to help you craft resolutions that stick.

Before jumping into goal-setting, it’s important to take a moment to reflect.

Think about what you achieved last year.

What moments brought you joy?

Were there any challenges that taught you valuable lessons?

Reflection helps you understand what worked and what didn’t, guiding you toward resolutions that align with your needs and values.

If you struggled with time management, you might want to focus on better planning.

If you felt disconnected from friends, a resolution to strengthen relationships could be meaningful.

One common mistake is making resolutions that are too vague.

Goals like “I want to be healthier” or “I’ll save money” are admirable, but they lack clarity.

Instead, make your goals specific.

Instead of saying “I’ll exercise more,” commit to “I will work out three times a week for 30 minutes.”

Specific goals are easier to follow and track, which increases your chances of success.

It’s great to aim high, but setting unrealistic goals can lead to frustration.

Start small and build up gradually.

Achieving smaller milestones will give you the confidence to tackle bigger challenges later.

Resolutions should challenge you without feeling impossible.

If you’ve never run a mile, aiming to complete a marathon in three months might not be practical.

Big goals can feel overwhelming, but breaking them into smaller steps makes them manageable.

For example, if your goal is to write a book, start by setting a target of writing 500 words a day.

Small, consistent actions add up over time.

This approach not only reduces stress but also keeps you motivated as you see progress.

Accountability is key to sticking with your resolutions.

Share your goals with a friend or family member who can encourage you along the way.

Some people find it helpful to join groups or online communities with similar interests.

Suppose, if you want to learn a new language, participating in a study group can keep you on track.

Life is unpredictable and sometimes our goals need adjustments.

If you hit a roadblock, don’t be discouraged.

Instead, reassess your approach.

Perhaps your original plan needs tweaking, or maybe you need more time to reach your target.

Flexibility allows you to adapt while still working toward your overall vision.

Resolutions often focus on the end goal, but it’s important to celebrate the small victories along the way.

Did you stick to your workout routine for a month? Treat yourself to something you enjoy, like a relaxing evening or a new book.

Acknowledging progress keeps you motivated and reminds you of how far you’ve come.

A well-rounded resolution list touches on various aspects of life.

Think about your physical health, mental well-being, relationships, career and personal growth.

You don’t have to address everything at once, but consider areas that could use more attention.

Balance ensures that you’re nurturing different parts of your life.

Representational Image

While New Year’s is a popular time for resolutions, remember that you can set goals anytime.

Don’t wait for January to make a positive change.

Whether it’s March, July, or October, the best time to start is now.

Every day is an opportunity to work toward the life you want.

The best resolutions are those that align with your values and passions.

Ask yourself why a particular goal matters to you.

For example, if you want to spend less time on social media, consider how it might improve your mental health or free up time for hobbies.

When your goals are meaningful, you’re more likely to stay committed.

This year, focus on personal growth by learning a new skill and practicing gratitude daily.

Prioritize health with a consistent workout routine and self-care.

Strengthen relationships by spending quality time with loved ones and listening actively.

Manage finances by budgeting, saving and reducing unnecessary spending.

Set clear career goals like pursuing a promotion or certification.

Contribute to the environment by reducing waste and planting a tree.

Travel to new places, explore creative hobbies, and give back by donating and mentoring others.

At its heart, setting resolutions is about growth and self-improvement

It’s not about being perfect or achieving everything on your list.

Instead, focus on the journey and the progress you make.

New Year’s resolutions are a chance to dream, plan and grow.

By reflecting on the past, setting clear and realistic goals and staying flexible, you can make this year one of positive change.

Remember, the most important step is the first one—so take it today!

title: Safeguard yourself in winter season
body:
As winter sets in, the chilly weather brings with it a range of health challenges.

From the common cold to respiratory infections the season can be tough on the immune system. The drop in temperature, dry air and limited sunlight makes the body more vulnerable to illnesses.

Conditions like the flu, bronchitis and sinusitis are more prevalent while skin issues like dryness and cracked lips become common.

Additionally, some people experience seasonal depression due to reduced exposure to natural light. To stay healthy, it’s essential to understand these risks and take proactive measures.

Simple lifestyle adjustments like staying hydrated, dressing warmly and boosting your diet with nutrient-rich foods can make a big difference.

Homemade remedies such as herbal teas and warm salt-water gargles offer relief from discomfort. Prevention through hygiene, vaccinations and proper ventilation is equally crucial.

Staying hydrated in winter is crucial because the cold, dry air can dehydrate your body without you realizing it.

Drinking water helps maintain energy levels and keeps your skin moisturized.

Eating immune-boosting foods, like citrus fruits, garlic, and leafy greens, strengthens your body's defense against seasonal illnesses like colds and flu.

Zinc-rich foods like nuts, seeds, and whole grains also help strengthen your body’s defenses.

These foods provide essential vitamins and minerals that support immune function, keeping you healthier during the colder months.

Applying lotion in winter is essential to keep the skin hydrated, as the dry, cold air can strip moisture from the skin, leading to dryness and irritation.

Lotion helps lock in moisture, keeping the skin soft and smooth. It also creates a protective barrier against harsh weather conditions, preventing cracks and discomfort.

A good option is a rich, nourishing lotion with ingredients like shea butter, glycerin or hyaluronic acid, which provide long-lasting hydration.

Brands like Nivea, Vaseline or Cetaphil offer moisturizing lotions that are gentle on the skin and effective in dry weather.

Regular application ensures your skin stays healthy and protected throughout the season.

Use humidifiers to combat drynessWinter air can be extremely dry, exacerbating respiratory issues and skin conditions.

Use a humidifier to maintain moisture levels in the air, which can prevent dry skin, sore throats, and sinus problems.

It improves indoor air quality, especially in dry climates or during winter.

Humidifiers can be easily found at most electronic stores, pharmacies or online marketplaces like Daraz. They come in various sizes and features, allowing you to choose one that suits your needs and room size.

Layering is essential in winter as it helps retain body heat by trapping warm air between layers, providing protection against the cold.

It allows for flexibility; you can add or remove layers based on changing temperatures or activity levels.

The base layer absorbs moisture, keeping the skin dry, while the middle layer provides warmth, and the outer layer shields against wind, rain, or snow.

Proper layering also prevents overheating and promotes breathability, ensuring comfort during outdoor activities.

Additionally, it helps adapt to various indoor and outdoor environments without compromising style or functionality.

Dress in layers and wear weather-appropriate clothing, including hats, gloves, earplugs, jackets with hoodies and socks, to protect yourself from cold temperatures.

Prolonged exposure to cold can weaken the immune system and lead to illnesses like colds or hypothermia.

Similarly, winter pollution, often worsened by fog and poor air quality, can harm respiratory health.

Wearing masks and warm clothing, staying indoors during peak pollution hours and using air purifiers can help reduce the risks.

Proper precautions ensure better protection for your overall well-being in challenging weather conditions.Avoid prolonged exposure to extreme cold and minimize time spent in areas with high pollution levels, which can worsen respiratory problems.

Wear a mask if needed.

Representational Image of Winter Safeguards

The crispness of winter can be harsh, especially on windy days.

Wearing a mask in winter helps protect against the dry, cold air that can irritate the respiratory system.

It also acts as a barrier to prevent the spread of germs, especially during flu season.

Masks can help retain moisture, keeping the airways hydrated and reducing discomfort caused by the cold.

Additionally, they offer protection from pollutants and allergens that are more concentrated in the winter air.

Chronic stress and lack of sleep weaken the immune system.

Cold weather and shorter days can affect mood and energy levels, making stress management even more important.

Regular exercise, meditation, or engaging in relaxing activities can help reduce stress.

Maintaining a consistent sleep schedule ensures the body gets enough rest to strengthen the immune system.

Proper stress and sleep management improve overall well-being and help combat the challenges of the winter season.

Practice stress management techniques like meditation, ensure you get 7–9 hours of sleep every night, and maintain a consistent sleep schedule.

If you experience symptoms such as persistent coughing, fever, severe body aches, or difficulty breathing, consult a doctor immediately.

Early intervention can prevent minor illnesses from escalating into serious conditions like bronchitis, pneumonia, or strep throat.

Delaying treatment can weaken your immune system and prolong recovery time.

Stay attentive to your health, and don't hesitate to seek medical advice if symptoms worsen or persist.

Quick action ensures timely care and reduces the risk of further complications.

To manage winter ailments and stay comfortable, try incorporating warm and natural remedies into your routine.

Herbal teas like ginger tea with honey, peppermint tea for congestion, chamomile tea for relaxation and turmeric tea for its anti-inflammatory properties are highly effective in soothing winter-related discomforts.

Gargle with warm salt water to ease a sore throat and reduce bacteria.

Steam inhalation with eucalyptus or peppermint oil can relieve nasal congestion and promote easier breathing.

Keep your skin hydrated with natural oils like coconut or olive oil, and use thick moisturizers to combat dryness.

Enjoy warm soups made with nutrient-rich vegetables and chicken broth to boost your immune system.

Additionally, homemade drinks like lemon water with honey or cinnamon-infused warm milk can provide comfort and strengthen your defenses against the cold.

Winter health is not just about treating illnesses but also about adopting habits that minimize risks.

Stay physically active with light indoor exercises like yoga or stretching, which improve circulation and immunity.

Prioritize quality sleep to allow your body to repair and rejuvenate.

Spend time outdoors in daylight to combat seasonal depression, but ensure you’re adequately bundled up to protect against the cold.

Reduce stress through mindfulness techniques, as chronic stress weakens the immune system.

Avoid prolonged exposure to cold temperatures, and if you must go out, cover exposed skin to prevent frostbite.

Keep an emergency kit with essentials like warm clothing, non-perishable foods, and basic medicines to prepare for severe weather or power outages.

These combined preventive measures and solutions will help you stay healthy and comfortable throughout the winter season. Winter doesn’t have to be a season of sickness—prepare well and enjoy it to the fullest.

title: Heavy security deployed nationwide as fears of election violence persist
body:
Ahead of the 13th National Parliamentary Election, the government and law enforcement agencies have completed extensive preparations to ensure security at polling stations across the country, amid lingering concerns over the potential for violence on election day.

To strengthen centre-based security, members of the police, Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) and Ansar will be deployed alongside personnel from the army, navy and air force. Other law enforcement and intelligence agencies will also remain on standby to maintain law and order. Technology-based surveillance systems are being integrated into the overall security plan.
